title: In The Matter Of The Care And Treatment Of John David Canupp
description: The State brought this action under the Sexually Violent Predator Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-48-10 to -170 (Supp. 2007) for a determination that Appellant was a sexually violent predator in need of involuntary civil commitment in a secure facility for long-term control, care, and treatment.  A jury found that Appellant was a sexually violent predator, and the trial court ordered that Appellant be committed to the South Carolina Department of Mental Health.  Appellant challenges the commitment order on the ground that the trial court failed to charge the jury that Appellant had a constitutional right to decline to take the witness stand.  The Court of Appeals held that Appellant had no such right and affirmed the circuit court's commitment order.

THE
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In
  The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        In
          The Matter Of The Care And Treatment Of John David Canupp, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal
From York County
Larry
R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion
No. 4463
Heard
November 6, 2008 â€“ Filed December 4, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate
          Defender Lanelle C. Durant, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster,
          Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah
          R.J. Shupe, Assistant Attorney General Brandy A. Duncan and Assistant Attorney General
          William M. Blitch, Jr., all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GEATHERS, J.:Â  The State
  brought this action under the Sexually Violent Predator Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  44-48-10 to -170 (Supp. 2007), for a determination that Appellant was a
  sexually violent predator in need of involuntary civil commitment in a secure
  facility for long-term control, care, and treatment.Â  A jury found that
  Appellant was a sexually violent predator, and the circuit court ordered that
  Appellant be committed to the South Carolina Department of Mental Health.Â 
  Appellant challenges the commitment order on the ground that the circuit court
  failed to charge the jury that Appellant had a constitutional right to decline
  to take the witness stand.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL
  HISTORY
    

On
  June 24, 2002, Appellant pled guilty to one count of committing a lewd act upon
  a child and was sentenced to fifteen years in prison, suspended upon the
  service of eight years and five years of probation.Â  While he was in prison,
  Appellant entered an Alford plea to a second count of committing a lewd
  act upon a child,[1] and, on January 22, 2003, he was sentenced to seven years in prison, to run
  concurrently with the first sentence.Â  Prior to his release from prison, Appellant
  was referred for review to determine if there was probable cause to believe
  that he met the definition of a sexually violent predator.Â  The circuit court
  determined that such probable cause existed and ordered Appellant to submit to
  an evaluation pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80.Â  Following the evaluation,
  the circuit court conducted a jury trial for a final determination of whether
  Appellant met the definition of a sexually violent predator pursuant to S.C.
Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-90.Â  
At trial, the State presented to the
  jury the indictments and sentencing sheets for Appellantâ€™s two convictions for
  sexually violent offenses.Â  Dr. Pamela Crawford, an expert in general
  psychiatry and forensic psychiatry, testified about the significance of the two
  events underlying the convictions.Â  Dr. Crawford expressed the opinion that
  Appellant met the criteria for a diagnosis of pedophilia and alcohol dependence
  and that he needed sex offender treatment.Â  She also stated that Appellant
  presented a significant likelihood of a repeat offense.Â  
Appellant presented the testimony of his
  stepdaughter and the programs manager for the York County Detention Center.Â  The stepdaughter, who was eleven or twelve years old when Appellant began living with
  her and her mother, stated that Appellant never acted inappropriately toward
  her.Â  The York County employee testified that, while Appellant was in prison, he
  had participated in the Life Skills program and also served as the chaplainâ€™s
  assistant.Â  Â Â 
After all of the evidence was presented,
  Appellantâ€™s counsel requested the circuit court to charge the jury that Appellant
  had a right to decline to take the witness stand.Â  The circuit court denied the
  request.Â  The jury later determined that Appellant was a sexually violent
  predator, and the circuit court issued an order committing Appellant to the
  South Carolina Department of Mental Health.Â  This appeal follows.
ISSUE ON APPEAL 
Did
  the circuit court commit reversible error in refusing to charge the jury that Appellant had a constitutional
  right to decline to take the witness stand?
STANDARD
OF REVIEW
The circuit
  court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  McCourt
    By and Through McCourt v. Abernathy,
  318 S.C. 301, 306, 457 S.E.2d 603, 606 (1995).Â  The
  law to be charged to the jury is determined by the evidence presented at
  trial.Â  State
    v. Hill,
  315 S.C. 260, 262, 433 S.E.2d 848, 849 (1993).Â  
In reviewing
  jury charges for error, this Court must consider the circuit courtâ€™s jury
  charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d
  570, 575 (1999). Â If, as a
  whole, the charges are reasonably free from error, isolated portions which
  might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.Â  Id.Â  A jury
  charge is correct if, when the charge is read as
  a whole, it contains the correct definition and adequately covers the law.Â  Id. at 495-96, 514 S.E.2d at 574.Â  
To warrant
  reversal, a circuit courtâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury charge must be
  both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.Â  State v. Patterson,
  367 S.C. 219, 232, 625 S.E.2d 239, 245 (Ct. App. 2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant
  contends that the circuit court erred when it denied counselâ€™s request to
  instruct the jury that Appellant had a constitutional right to decline to take
  the witness stand.Â  Appellant specifically argues that, as one subject to
  proceedings under South
  Carolinaâ€™s
  Sexually Violent Predator Act (the Act), he should have the same constitutional
  rights as a criminal defendant because the same personal freedom is at stake.[2]Â 
  Appellant also argues that this omission prejudiced him because there is a
  reasonable probability that the outcome would have been different if the
  circuit court had given the requested charge.Â  We disagree.
The
  Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution sets forth the right against
  self-incrimination as follows:Â  â€œNo person . . . shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a
  witness against himself . . . . â€Â  U.S. Const.
  amend. V.Â  The South Carolina Constitution also provides for a right against
  self-incrimination: Â â€œ[N]or shall any person be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness
  against himself.â€Â  S.C. Const. art.
  I, Â§ 12.Â  
Similarly, a witness in a civil action may
  decline to answer a certain question if there is a reasonable possibility that the
  answer would provide information that could be used against the witness in a
  criminal proceeding or would lead to the discovery of such information.Â  See Grosshuesch v. Cramer, 377 S.C. 12, 24, 659 S.E.2d 112, 118 (2008); see also State v.
    Hook, 348 S.C. 401, 415, 559 S.E.2d 856, 863 (Ct.
  App. 2001) (quoting Lefkowitz v. Turley, 414 U.S. 70, 77-78 (1973) and stating that the Fifth
  Amendment â€œnot only protects the individual against being involuntarily called
  as a witness against himself in a criminal prosecution but also privileges him
  not to answer official questions put to him in any other proceeding, civil or
  criminal, formal or informal, where the answers might incriminate him in future
  criminal proceedings.â€), modified on other grounds, 356 S.C. 421, 590 S.E.2d 25 (2003).
Nonetheless, only
  a criminal defendant has the right to decline to take the witness stand
  altogether.Â  See Baxter v. Palmigiano, 425
  U.S. 308 (1976)
  (citing prevailing rule that the Fifth Amendment does not forbid
  adverse inferences against parties to civil actions when they refuse to testify
  in response to probative evidence offered against them and holding
  that permitting an adverse inference to be drawn from an inmateâ€™s
  silence at civil disciplinary proceedings is not, on its face, an invalid
  practice). 
While the Act bestows some of the rights
  normally associated with criminal prosecutions,[3] it is not intended to be punitive in nature; rather, it
  sets forth a civil process for the commitment and treatment of sexually violent
  predators. Â In
    re Matthews,
  345 S.C. 638, 649, 550 S.E.2d 311, 316 (2001) (noting that, in Kansas v. Hendricks, 521 U.S. 346 (1997), the United
  States Supreme Court deemed Kansasâ€™ Sexually Violent Predator Act, on which the
  South Carolina Act is modeled, to be a civil, non-punitive scheme);[4] In re Care
    and Treatment of Brown v. State, 372 S.C. 611, 616, 643 S.E.2d 118, 121 (Ct.
  App. 2007).Â  The Act is designed to: (1) meet the
  special needs of sexually violent predators; (2) address the
  significant likelihood that they will engage in repeated acts of sexual
  violence if not treated for their mental conditions; and (3) assess the risks
  requiring their involuntary civil commitment in a secure facility for long-term
  control, care, and treatment. Â Id. at 616-617, 643 S.E.2d at 121 (citing
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
44-48-20 (Supp. 2006)).Â  
Appellant has not cited, nor has our
  research revealed, any South Carolina authority to support his argument that there
  exists a constitutional right to decline to take
  the witness stand in a commitment trial under the Act.Â  Notably,
  existing federal precedent indicates that there exists no such right under the
  United States Constitution.Â  See Kansas v.
    Hendricks, 521 U.S. 346 (1997) (stating that the State may take measures
  to restrict the freedom of the dangerously mentally ill and that such
  restriction is a legitimate, non-punitive governmental objective); Allen v.
    Illinois, 478 U.S. 364 (1986) (holding that proceedings under Illinoisâ€™
  Sexually Dangerous Persons Act were not â€œcriminalâ€ within meaning of Fifth
  Amendmentâ€™s guarantee against compulsory self-incrimination because commitment
  to maximum security institution that also housed convicts needing psychiatric
  care did not make conditions of personâ€™s confinement amount to â€œpunishmentâ€).[5]Â 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In
  any event, the omission of the requested charge did not prejudice Appellant.Â 
  Even if the circuit court had given the requested charge, the jury had before
  it overwhelming evidence that Appellant met the statutory definition of a
  sexually violent predator, which is as follows:

  
    â€œSexually
      violent predatorâ€ means a person
      who:
    (a) has been
      convicted of a sexually violent offense; and
    (b) suffers from
      a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes the person likely to
      engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for
      long-term control, care, and treatment.
  

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(1) (Supp. 2007).Â  
The evidence presented to the jury shows
  that Appellant pled guilty to the sexual assault of a seven-year-old girl
  between 1995 and 1996 and that he also entered an Alford plea to the sexual
  assault of a child under the age of sixteen between the spring of 1995 and the
  summer of 1996.Â  Dr. Crawford testified about the significance of the two
  events underlying the convictions.Â  She stated that the events show a pattern
  of behavior involving sexual contact with prepubescent girls.Â  Â Â 
Dr. Crawford also gave her observations
  from her interviews with Appellant.Â  She stated that Appellantâ€™s inconsistency
  in his rendition of the events showed her that he did not appear to be fully
  accepting responsibility for his actions.Â  Dr. Crawford also indicated that
  Appellant was sexually aggressive, that he denied that he was sexually
  attracted to children despite evidence of a series of events, and that he did
  not believe that he needed sex offender treatment.Â  Â Â 
Dr. Crawford expressed the opinion that
  Appellant met the criteria for a diagnosis of pedophilia and alcohol dependence
  and that he needed sex offender treatment.Â  Dr. Crawford explained that
  pedophilia is typically a life-long behavioral disorder.Â  She also stated that
  Appellantâ€™s pedophilia affects his ability to control his behavior, that he is
  predisposed to commit future acts of sexual violence, and that he would present
  a danger to prepubescent children.Â  Dr. Crawford expressed her opinion that
  Appellant presented a significant likelihood of a repeat offense.Â  
Dr. Crawford acknowledged that approximately
  one year had elapsed between her interviews with Appellant and the commitment
  trial, and she qualified her opinions on that basis.Â  However, no expert
  testimony was offered to assist the jury in determining whether Appellant had received
  any professional treatment or had made any significant progress during that
  one-year period.Â  Therefore, the jury was presented with overwhelming evidence
  that Appellant met the definition of a sexually violent predator.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit
  courtâ€™s refusal to charge the jury that Appellant had a constitutional right to
  decline to take the witness stand was neither erroneous nor prejudicial.Â  Under
  the current law, there exists no constitutional right to decline to take the
  witness stand in a civil proceeding, and it is not disputed that proceedings
  under the Act are civil in nature.Â  Further, any adverse inference, permissible
  or impermissible, that the jury might have drawn from Appellantâ€™s absence from
  the witness stand would not be outcome determinative in light of the
  overwhelming evidence that Appellant met the Actâ€™s definition of a sexually
  violent predator.Â  Accordingly,
  the circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS,
  J., and PIEPER, J., concur.


[1] See North
  Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970), which discusses the acceptance of a
guilty plea from a defendant who maintains his innocence.
[2] Appellant
  concedes that the commitment of a sexually violent predator under the Act is
civil in nature.
[3] The Act
  provides for a
  probable cause hearing, the assistance of counsel, a jury trial, the right to
  cross-examine witnesses, and the right to view and copy all petitions and
  reports in the court file.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80 (Supp. 2007).Â  Additionally,
  the Act adopts the burden of proof required in criminal prosecutions; S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 44-48-100(A) (Supp. 2007) requires that a determination of whether one
  is a sexually violent predator be made only upon proof beyond a reasonable
doubt.Â  
[4] In Matthews,
  the South Carolina Supreme Court found that the appellant did not effectively
  distinguish the Kansas Act from South Carolinaâ€™s Act; therefore, South Carolinaâ€™s Act violated neither the Double Jeopardy Clause of the United States
  Constitution nor that of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  Matthews, 345
S.C. at 649-51, 550 S.E.2d at 316-17.Â  
[5]See also Joan
  Comparet-Cassani, A Primer on the Civil Trial of a Sexually Violent Predator,
  37 San Diego L. Rev. 1057, 1109-15 (2000) (examining Californiaâ€™s Sexually
Violent Predator Act and applicable federal constitutional law).

title: Crusader Servicing Corporation v. County of Laurens
description: Following a delinquent tax sale, the Department of Revenue determined Southeastern Housing Foundation was exempt from taxes.  As a result, the County of Laurens returned Crusader Servicing Corporationâ€™s bid.  All parties appeal the special refereeâ€™s determination that the County of Laurens was liable to Crusader for statutory interest but not prejudgment interest.  Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Crusader Servicing
      Corporation, Respondent/Appellant,
				v.
				The County of Laurens,
      South Carolina, a Body Politic, and Southeastern Housing Foundation, Appellants/Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Laurens County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Special Referee
Opinion No. 4464
Heard October 22, 2008 â€“ Filed December 4,
  2008
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled
  February 26, 2009
AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Robert
  Hill, of Newberry and Benjamin Goldberg, of Charleston, for
  Respondent/Appellant.
				William
  Douglas Gray, of Anderson, for Appellant/Respondent, Laurens County.
				Richard B. Ness, of Bamberg, for Appellant/Respondent,
  Southeastern Housing Foundation.
			
		
	

KONDUROS,
  J.:Â  Laurens County (the County) and Southeastern Housing
    Foundation (Southeastern) appeal the special refereeâ€™s finding they were
    jointly and severally liable to Crusader Servicing Corporation (Crusader) for
    bid interest related to a delinquent tax sale.Â  Crusader cross-appeals alleging
    the special referee erred in denying its request for statutory prejudgment
    interest.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
Southeastern failed
  to pay ad valorem property taxes for 2001 and 2002 for its property
  located in Laurens County and known as the Westside Manor Apartments.Â  In 2003,
  the County proceeded with a tax sale of the property.Â  Crusader bid $348,000[1] for the property and deposited the bid money with the County.Â  Southeastern
  claimed it was tax exempt and filed for such status with the Department of
  Revenue (the Department) subsequent to the sale of the property.[2]Â 
  Two days prior to the expiration of the redemption period, Southeastern paid
  the taxes due to Laurens County plus twelve percent Â interest to be given to
  Crusader as the bidder pursuant to section 12-51-90(B) of the South Carolina
  Code (Supp. 2007).Â  Four days later, the Department awarded Southeastern tax
  exempt status for the year 2002.Â  Laurens County returned $67,569.00 to Southeastern,
  which specifically included the twelve percent interest on Crusaderâ€™s bid.Â  
The
  County sent a letter to Crusader indicating the tax sale was void and
  requesting return of the tax sale receipt to the property in exchange for a
  refund of the bid amount.Â  Crusader refused to return the tax sale receipt at
  that time, arguing it was entitled to the twelve percent interest under the
  redemption statute.Â  The parties eventually entered a consent order in August
  of 2005 pursuant to which Crusader returned the tax sale receipt, and the
  County returned the bid money to Crusader.
Litigation
  ensued, and the special referee concluded Southeastern and Laurens County were
  jointly and severally liable for the twelve percent bid interest.Â  The court
  reasoned the redemption statute provided for the payment of the interest.Â  The
  court found the County was without authority under section 12-51-100 of the
  South Carolina Code (2000) to void a tax sale unless they made a procedural
  error in the conduct of the sale.Â  The County and Southeastern appeal.Â  Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe sale of the property of a defaulting taxpayer is governed by
  statute.â€Â  Key Corporate Capital Inc., v. County of Beaufort, 373 S.C.
  55, 59, 644 S.E.2d 675, 677 (2007).Â  Statutory interpretation is a question of
  law.Â  State v. Sweat, 379 S.C. 367, 373, 665 S.E. 2d 645, 648 (Ct. App.
  2008).Â  â€œWhen an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed facts, an appellate
  court is free to review whether the trial court properly applied the law to
  those facts. In such cases, the appellate court is not required to defer to the
  trial courtâ€™s legal conclusions.â€ Â Id., 665 S.E. 2d at 649.Â  â€œIf a
  statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning, â€˜the
  rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to
  impose another meaning.â€™â€Â  Buist v. Huggins, 367 S.C. 268, 276, 625
  S.E.2d 636, 640 (2006) (quoting Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533
  S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000)). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Bid Interest Under Sections 12-51-90, 12-51-100, and 12-51-150 of the South
  Carolina Code
Southeastern contends the special referee erred in finding it
  liable to Crusader for bid interest pursuant to section 12-51-90 of the South
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) because the tax sale was voided once Southeastern
  was declared tax exempt for 2002.Â  We disagree.
Under
  section 12-51-90(A), the defaulting taxpayer may redeem the affected property
  within the redemption period by paying delinquent taxes, assessments, penalties, and costs, together with
  interest as provided in subsection (B).Â  Subsection (B) requires the delinquent
  taxpayer to remit interest on the tax sale bid amount in accordance with the
  schedule set forth.Â  For property redeemed in the final three months of the
  redemption period, the interest rate is twelve percent.Â  Section 12-51-100 of
  the South Carolina Code (2000) dictates what happens when the redemption is
  instituted:Â  â€œThe successful purchaser, at the delinquent tax sale, shall
  promptly be notified by mail to return the tax sale receipt to the person
  officially charged with the collection of delinquent taxes in order to be
  expeditiously refunded the purchase price plus the interest provided in
    Section 12-51-90.â€ (emphasis added).
Section
  12-51-150 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) governs the procedure for
  voiding a tax sale:Â  

	If the official in charge of the tax sale discovers before a tax
  title has passed that there is a failure of any action required to be properly
  performed, the official may void the tax sale and refund the amount paid, plus
  interest in the amount actually earned by the county on the amount refunded, to
  the successful bidder.Â  If the full amount of the taxes, assessments,
  penalties, and costs have not been paid, the property must be brought to tax sale
  as soon as possible.

The statutory
  framework for tax sales does not seem to contemplate the precise situation
  presented in this case.Â  The interest provision of section 12-51-90(B) is
  intended to encourage the prompt payment of delinquent taxes and to penalize the
  delinquent taxpayer for delay.Â  Furthermore, the interest provision is an
  incentive for purchasers to bid on tax sale property even though there is risk
  involved that the property could be redeemed or the sale voided altogether.[3]
Once the redemption
  was accomplished by Southeastern under section 12-51-90, the terms of section 12-51-100
  were triggered, and Crusader was entitled to the twelve percent interest on its
  bid.Â  Section 12-51-150 does not provide that the official in charge of conducting
  the sale can void the sale because taxes were wrongfully assessed and the
  property was tax exempt. Â It only addresses situations in which the sale was
  not properly conducted.Â  We decline to read more into the statute than can be
  discerned from its plain language.Â  See Buist v. Huggins, 367 S.C. 268, 276, 625 S.E.2d 636, 640
  (2006) (finding the court cannot impose another meaning on plain statutory
  language).Â  Therefore, we cannot conclude
  the sale was void pursuant to section 12-51-150.Â  
However,
  as Southeastern points out, section
  12-4-730 of the South Carolina Code (2000) permits the county auditor to â€œvoid
  any tax notice applicable to the propertyâ€ once notified by the department that
  a property is exempt from ad valorem taxes.Â  We
  do not find it necessary to determine whether the auditor could retroactively
  void the tax notice thereby nullifying the sale.Â  The record shows Southeastern
  did not pay, nor did it attempt to pay, the 2001 back taxes until after the tax
  sale.Â  It is undisputed Southeastern was ultimately responsible for paying
  those taxes.Â  The county was within its rights to proceed with a sale of the
  subject property based on the outstanding taxes owed for 2001.Â  The failure to
  pay the undisputedly due taxes validates the sale even if the tax notice for
  the 2002 taxes was retroactively voided.Â  Consequently, the sale was valid, the
  redemption was valid, and the subsequent determination of tax exempt status for
  2002 did not affect the sale.Â  The tax exempt determination entitled Southeastern
  to the refund of taxes assessed for 2002, but did not render the requirements
  under sections 12-51-90 and 12-51-100 ineffective.Â  Therefore, we find the
  special referee correctly concluded Southeastern was required to pay the bid
  interest to the County of Laurens to be remitted to Crusader.
The
  County argues it should not be responsible for payment of the bid interest to
  Crusader.Â  We agree.Â  Under the statute, the person officially charge with the
  collection of delinquent taxes should â€œexpeditiously refund the purchase price
  plus the interest provided in Section 12-51-90.â€Â  Â§ 12-51-100.Â  Under section 12-51-90,
  it is the defaulting taxpayer, in this case Southeastern, who is responsible
  for paying the bid interest.Â  The County, under the statute, is responsible
  for remitting the paid money to the bidder as part of the redemption process.Â  
Our analysis with
  respect to the Countyâ€™s liability must be performed in light of another case
  from this court, H & K Specialists v. Brannen, 340 S.C. 585, 532
  S.E.2d 617 (2000).Â  In H & K Specialists, the Beaufort County
  treasurer provided improper notice regarding the tax sale of the property.Â  Id. at 586, 532 S.E.2d at 618.Â  After the title to the property had passed to the
  successful bidder, H&K, the treasurer set aside the sale and refunded the
  purchase price less the tax delinquency to the defaulting taxpayers, the
  Brannens.Â  Id.Â  H&K then sued Beaufort County for the return of its
  purchase price plus statutory interest as provided under the redemption
  statute. Â Id.Â  In finding the County liable for the funds, the court
  stated:

	Finally,
  we are mindful of the fact that the master based his decision, in part, on the
  fact that the Brannens received both the property and the money and thus
  H&Kâ€™s sole remedy was against the Brannens.Â  However, it was the Beaufort
  County Respondents which created this inequitable situation by failing to
  provide the Brannens with the proper notice that resulted in the tax sale being
  set aside and erred in refunding the purchase price, less the tax delinquency,
  to the Brannens rather than to H&K.Â  Therefore, we do not believe H&K
  is limited to pursuing a legal remedy solely against the Brannens. 

Id. at 589, 532 S.E.2d at 619-20.
In
  this case, the County does not appear to be responsible for the inequity that
  has resulted to the parties.Â  Southeastern neglected to pay its 2001 taxes and
  was not as diligent as it should have been in ascertaining the status of its
  tax exemption for 2002.Â  Had Southeastern paid the taxes due and then sought a
  refund, the property would not have been sold, thereby avoiding the present
  scenario.Â  
The
  County was faced with a legitimate conundrum in light of the Departmentâ€™s
  notice of tax exemption being issued almost simultaneously with the
  redemption.Â  The County consulted its legal counsel, and based on that advice
  proceeded to refund the 2002 taxes and the bid interest paid to Southeastern
  believing the sale to be legally void at that time.Â  The County then attempted
  to return the purchase price to Crusader as mandated and was willing to return
  the interest actually earned.Â Â Â  
We
  do not find statutory authority for requiring the County to pay the bid
  interest to Crusader, and we find the present facts distinguishable from those
  present in H&K Specialists so that the County should not be found
  jointly and severally liable with Southeastern for the bid interest.Â 
  Therefore, we conclude the bid interest was properly due to Crusader under
  section 12-51-100, but only Southeastern, the defaulting taxpayer thereunder,
  is liable for payment.
II.  Statutory Prejudgment
  Interest on the Bid Interest
Crusader
  contends the special referee erred in denying its request for statutory
  prejudgment interest on the bid interest it was due under the redemption
  statute.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
Section 34-31-20(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) provides
  â€œ[i]n all cases of accounts
  stated and in all cases wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained
  and, being due, shall draw interest according to law, the legal interest
  shall be at the rate of eight and three-fourths percent per annum.â€ (emphasis
  added).Â  Prejudgment interest is allowed if the sum is certain or capable of
  being reduced to certainty based on a mathematical calculation previously
  agreed to by the parties.Â  Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court St., LLC,
  369 S.C. 121, 133, 631 S.E.2d 252, 258-59 (2006).Â Â  
In the instant case, the sum due to Crusader was the bid interest
  under the redemption statute.Â  Although the bid interest ultimately would be
  paid to Crusader, the statute required the money first pass from Southeastern through
  the County.Â  According to the County, the bid interest was no longer due and
    owing.Â  Consequently, the sum was removed from the purview of section
  34-31-20(A), and Crusader is not entitled to statutory prejudgment interest.Â  
III.  Statutory Interest
  on the Bid 
The County contends the special referee erred
  in awarding Crusader $25,375 in interest on Crusader's $348,000 bid.Â  We agree.
The special
  referee awarded statutory prejudgment interest pursuant to section 34-31-20(A) for the period of time in
  which the County held Crusader's bid money while awaiting return of the tax
  sale receipt.Â  According to section 12-51-100, "[t]he successful purchaser, at the delinquent tax sale,
  shall promptly be notified by mail to return the tax sale receipt to the person
  officially charged with the collection of delinquent taxes in order to be
    expeditiously refunded the purchase price plus the interest provided in section
  12-51-90." (emphasis added).Â  Thus, as
  a condition precedent to return of the bid, the bidder is required to return
  the tax sale receipt.Â  Therefore, we find
  the County is not liable for prejudgment interest on Crusader's bid for the
  time in which Crusader retained the tax sale receipt after notification by the
  County.
CONCLUSION
We
  find Southeastern liable for the bid interest due to Crusader pursuant to
  section 12-51-100, but
  Southeastern is not responsible for statutory prejudgment interest.Â  We
  conclude this case is distinguishable from H & K Specialists so that
  the County is not responsible for payment of the bid interest or statutory
  prejudgment interest.Â  We further find the County is not liable for prejudgment
  interest on Crusader's bid for the time in which Crusader retained the tax sale
  receipt.Â  Therefore, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED
  IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
ANDERSON and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] This was a clear overbid for the property. 
[2] The record is unclear whether Southeastern may have
  at some point been declared tax exempt for the year 2001, but it is undisputed
  that Southeastern was assessed the taxes, failed to pay them in a timely
  manner, and was ultimately found liable for the ad valorem taxes
  for 2001.Â  
[3] We recognize section 12-51-150 provides the bidder is
  entitled to the interest actually accrued on the bid amount in the event the
  sale is voided.

title: Trey Gowdy v. Gibson
description: The Gibsons argue the trial court erred in affirming the seizure and forfeiture of $146,050 in cash arising out of the discovery of drugs and paraphernalia.  The Gibsons contend the trial court erred in failing to grant them a directed verdict because the State presented no evidence the money was related to the drugs.  The Gibsons further maintain they presented sufficient evidence the money was unrelated to the drugs. Affirmed.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Trey Gowdy, as Solicitor
          for The Seventh Judicial
          Circuit, Respondent,
        v.
        Bobby Gibson, Jr. and
          Lillie Gibson, Appellants.
        IN REM:
        $146,050.00 in U.S. Currency
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4465
  Heard October 21, 2008 â€“ Filed December 4,
2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Miles
          F. Weaver, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Robin
          C. File, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KONDUROS,
  J: Bobby Gibson, Jr. (Gibson) and his
  mother, Lillie Gibson, appeal the trial courtâ€™s confirmation of the forfeiture
  of $146,050 pursuant to section 44-53-520 of the South Carolina Code (2002 &
  Supp. 2007).Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In September 2004, Gibson
  was under investigation by the Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s Office for drug
  activity.Â  When officers stopped Gibson for driving under suspension, they
  searched him and discovered a single crack rock in the bottom of his cell phone
  case.Â  Based on this discovery, police obtained a search warrant for 2015 Howard Street in Spartanburg, where Gibson lived with his mother, Lillie Gibson.Â  When
  executing the warrant, police found a small fire safe in the attic, which could
  only be accessed through a hole cut in the ceiling of the closet in Gibsonâ€™s
  bedroom.Â  Before opening the safe, officers allowed the narcotics canine to
  sniff the safe and the dog alerted on it.Â  The safe contained $146,050 as well
  as a small metal box containing an unknown amount of currency and old coins.Â 
  Mrs. Gibson did not know the combination to the safe and made no claim of
  ownership to the money at that time.Â  Officers also found $3,000 in the trunk
  of a car located at the home.Â  Officers seized the $146,050 but elected not to
  seize the metal box or the $3,000.
A search of the
  premises outside the house yielded a set of digital scales, a plastic medicine
  bottle containing 24.4 grams of crack cocaine, and a plastic bag containing
  11.7 grams of marijuana.Â  The items were found approximately 140 feet from the
  location of the safe, concealed under bricks, behind a detached garage located
  behind the residence.
Another search
  warrant was executed at 420 Farley Street, the location of a building being remodeled
  by Gibson for use as a beauty salon.Â  A plastic bag containing 713 grams of
  cocaine was found hidden in the ceiling at that location. 
The solicitor filed
  the underlying civil action to confirm the seizure and forfeiture of the money
  alleging it was Gibsonâ€™s property and was subject to forfeiture under section
  44-53-520 of the South Carolina Code (2002 & Supp. 2007).Â  Mrs. Gibson was
  added as a party to the action based on her claim to the money.Â  
The circuit court determined the money was
  subject to forfeiture â€œbecause it was traceable to illegal transactions based
  on the facts presented in this case.â€Â  The court made its finding â€œapplying the
  [] standard in Pope v. Gordon, 359 S.C. 572, 598 S.E.2d 288 (2004),â€
  which recognized a totality of the circumstances analysis for determining
  probable cause.Â  The court cited the close proximity of the money to evidence of
  illegal drug activity, Gibsonâ€™s history of drug activity, and the failure to
  provide a plausible explanation for a legitimate source for the funds as a
  basis for its ruling.Â  The court also relied on the credibility of the
  testifying officers to determine the forfeiture was appropriate.Â  This appeal
  followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action for
  forfeiture of property is a civil action at law.â€Â  Pope v. Gordon, 369
  S.C. 469, 474, 633 S.E.2d 148, 151 (2006).Â  In an action at law, tried by a
  judge, the appellate court standard of review extends only to the correction of
  errors of law.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact will not be disturbed
  on appeal unless the findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or
  controlled by an erroneous conception of the application of the law.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. The Stateâ€™s Case Under Section 44-53-520 of
  the South Carolina Code[1]
The Gibsons contend the State failed to establish the seized funds
  were in close proximity to evidence of illegal drug activity or were traceable
  to illegal drug activity.Â  We disagree.
The purpose of a forfeiture hearing is to
  confirm the state had probable cause to seize the property in question. Medlock
    v. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee VIN 1JCWB7828FT129001, 322 S.C. 127, 131, 470 S.E.2d 373,
  376 (1996).Â  â€œProbable cause is defined as a good faith belief that a person is
  guilty of a crime when this belief rests on such grounds as would induce an ordinarily
  prudent and cautious person, under the circumstances, to believe likewise.â€Â  Lynch
    v. Toys â€œRâ€ Us - Del.,
      Inc., 375 S.C. 604, 616-17, 654 S.E.2d 541, 548 (Ct.
  App. 2007) (citing Jones v. City of Columbia, 301 S.C. 62, 65, 389
  S.E.2d 662, 663 (1990)).Â  
Section 44-53-520 of the South Carolina Code (2002 &
  Supp. 2007) enumerates what property is subject to forfeiture in a criminal
  action.Â  Sub-parts (7) and (8) are the sub-parts of concern to us in this
  case.Â  

  (a) The following are
    subject to forfeiture . . . 
  
  (7) all property
    including, but not limited to, monies, negotiable instruments, securities, or
    other things of value furnished or intended to be furnished by any person in
    exchange for a controlled substance, and all proceeds including, but not
    limited to, monies, and real and personal property traceable to any exchange;
  (8) all monies seized in close proximity
    to forfeitable controlled substances, drug manufacturing, or distributing
    paraphernalia, or in close proximity to forfeitable records of the importation,
    manufacturing, or distribution of controlled substances and all monies seized
    at the time of arrest or search involving violation of this article. If
    the person from whom the monies were taken can establish to the satisfaction of
    a court of competent jurisdiction that the monies seized are not products of
    illegal acts, the monies must be returned pursuant to court order.

Id.
The Gibsons contend the relationship
  between the locations of the money and the drugs and drug paraphernalia did not
  constitute close proximity as contemplated by the statute.Â  No South Carolina cases discuss precisely how close proximity is to be measured.Â  However, we
  do not find it necessary to determine what distance constitutes close proximity
  for purposes of sub-part (8).Â  Although the circuit court stated the money was
  found in close proximity to evidence of illegal drug activity, that finding is
  not the sole basis for the courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Rather, proximity appears to be one
  of several factors the court considered in determining the money was
  â€œtraceableâ€ to illegal drug activity under sub-part (7).Â  
Therefore, we turn our attention to whether the State
  established probable cause the money was traceable to illegal drug activity.Â  Traceability
  was recently discussed by our supreme court in Pope v. Gordon,
  369 S.C. 469, 633 S.E.2d 148 (2006).Â  In that case, police seized a business bank
  account of the claimant, who was convicted of trafficking in cocaine.Â  Id. at 473, 633 S.E.2d at 150.Â  The State presented evidence Gordon paid for his
  monthly rent in cash and did not file tax returns for 1995 and 1996.Â  Id. at 475, 633 S.E.2d at 151-52. Â The State further contended Gordonâ€™s expenses
  exceeded his business income.Â  Id. at 475-76, 633 S.E.2d at 152.Â  The
  court concluded:Â  

  The record shows that [Gordon] did have a legitimate car
    detailing business that involved cash transactions.Â  In addition, the bank
    records show that money in the accounts came from the car detailing business.Â 
    As a result, the State failed to demonstrate how the money contained in the
    bank account came from illegal drug transactions.Â  

Id. at 476, 633 S.E.2d at 152.
The Pope court went on to reject a totality of the circumstances approach set forth in United
  States v. Thomas, 913 F.2d 1111 (4th Cir. 1990).Â  In Thomas, the fourth
  circuit examined the governmentâ€™s evidence in toto in determining there
  was probable cause to seize certain property of Thomasâ€™ including a $25,000
  bond.Â  Id. at 1114-15, 1117.Â  The court considered Thomasâ€™ unusual
  travel patterns, one-way trips to Miami, prior drug activity, and excessive
  expenditures for his legitimate income.Â  Id. at 1115-17.Â  The court
  concluded the evidence, â€œ[i]n its totality,â€ strongly implicated Thomas in
  illegal drug activity.Â  Id. at 1117.Â  In rejecting this approach our
  supreme court stated: â€œ[W]e decline to use the rationale in Thomas because
  we believe the standard in Thomas would lessen the burden on the State
  and is in direct contravention to the word traceable in the language of the
  statute.â€Â  Pope, 369 S.C. at 476, 633 S.E.2d at 152.Â  
With all the
  foregoing in mind, we find this case to be distinguishable from Thomas and Pope.Â  As previously discussed, the money in this case was found
  hidden in the ceiling of Gibsonâ€™s bedroom, and drugs and drug paraphernalia
  were discovered on the property.Â  Furthermore, the drug dog at the scene
  alerted to the safe indicating the safe or its contents had at some point in
  time been in contact with illegal narcotics.Â  Additionally, drugs were found at
  the beauty shop, another location under Gibsonâ€™s control.
While our
  analysis does look at several pieces of evidence, we do not believe this is the
  type of totality of the circumstances analysis set forth in Thomas and
  disapproved of in Pope.Â  We believe the evidence presented in this case
  is much more compelling and does not require making the kinds of assumptions
  that would have been required in Pope.Â  Drugs were found on the same
  property with the money.Â  The funds were hidden in a location that was
  inaccessible to the alleged owner.Â  Mrs. Gibson made no claim to the money at
  the time it was seized and, very significantly, the drug dog alerted on the
  safe making it more likely than not the money and/or the safe had been in
  contact with drugs.[2]
We think it
  important to note, Pope is factually distinguishable from the case sub
    judice.Â  The money at issue in Pope was in a business bank account,
  which would necessitate tracing the funds through some type of documentation or
  testimony the money was not the product of legitimate business.Â  In this case,
  the actual currency was found during the execution of a search warrant seeking
  illegal drugs.Â Â  
In Pope,
  the court expressed concern over lessening the burden on the State to prove its
  case.Â  We agree mere suspicion and innuendo should not be mistaken for the
  establishment of probable cause.Â  However, the State was not required to prove with
  certainty the money was connected to illegal drug transactions.Â  The statute
  requires the State to establish probable cause the seized money was traceable
  to drug activity.Â  We believe, under the particularized circumstances of this
  case, the State met its burden.
II. The Gibsonsâ€™
  Rebuttal
The Gibsons
  further argue they satisfied the burden of showing by a preponderance of the
  evidence the money belonged to Mrs. Gibson and constituted her life savings.Â 
  We disagree.Â  
â€œIf probable cause is shown, the burden
  shifts to the owner to show by the preponderance of the evidence that he or she
  â€˜was not a consenting party to, or privy to, or did not have knowledge of, the
  use of the property which made it subject to seizure and forfeiture.â€™â€ Â Â Medlock,
  322 S.C. at 131, 470
  S.E.2d at 376 (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-586(b)(1) (Supp.
  1994)).Â  
Mrs. Gibson was
  under a higher burden than the State and was required to prove her claim to the
  money by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  Mrs. Gibson testified the money seized
  was her life savings.Â  She testified she had worked at the same company for
  twenty-seven years and at the time of trial earned $14.33 per hour.Â  Mrs.
  Gibson indicated she sometimes worked as much as sixty hours per week being
  paid time-and-a-half for any time over forty hours.Â  Mrs. Gibson also claimed
  she had some money from illegal gambling.Â  She testified she did not keep the
  money in the bank because she had lost money that way before and the safe was
  in the attic because it would be safer in the event of a break-in.Â  Mrs. Gibson
  admitted she could not access the safe herself and did not know the
  combination.
Mrs. Gibson was
  unable to provide any documentation regarding a legitimate source for the money
  or to in any way rebut the evidence presented by the state the money was
  connected to illegal drug activity.Â  Furthermore, the circuit court did not
  find Gibson or Mrs. Gibson to be credible regarding their explanation for the
  money.Â  Although not bound by that conclusion, we generally defer to the
  findings of the trial judge in that regard.Â  See USAA Prop. &
    Cas. Ins. Co. v. Clegg, 377 S.C. 643, 652-53, 661 S.E.2d 791, 796 (2008)
  (â€œ[N]oting the circuit court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, is in a
  better position to evaluation their credibility and assign comparative weight
  to their testimony.â€) (citing Reed v. Ozmint, 374 S.C. 19, 24, 647
  S.E.2d 209, 211 (2007)). 
For all of the
  foregoing reasons, the determination of the trial court is
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON and
  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] The discussion in this section encompasses the third
  issue raised on appeal regarding the trial courtâ€™s use of the standard set
forth in Pope v. Gordon, 359 S.C. 572, 598 S.E.2d 288 (Ct. App. 2004).
[2] While some courts disapprove of the admission of drug
  canine alerts, the Gibsons did not object to the admission of the testimony in
this case.

title: McCall v. IKON
description: This is a  breach of contract action that initially arose before this court following a default judgment entered against IKON.  Following remand of the matter to the circuit court for a new hearing on damages, the circuit court determined McCall sustained damages in the amount of $24, 379.33. McCall now appeals asserting error in the court's determination of damages and the admission and or interpretation of certain evidence.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jonathan S.
      McCall, Appellant,
				v.
				IKON, d/b/a
      IKON Educational Services, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4466
Heard November 19, 2008 â€“ Filed December
  12, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Duke K. McCall, Jr., of Greenville for Appellant.
				Sandi R. Wilson and Keith D. Munson, of Greenville for Respondent.
			
		
	

HUFF,
  J.:Â  Jonathan S. McCall appeals from an order of the
  circuit court finding him entitled to damages of $24,379.33 on his breach of
  contract action against IKON Educational Services.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  HISTORY
This matter originally came before this court on IKONâ€™s appeal
  from the denial of relief from a default judgment against it and in favor of
  McCall.Â  Finding IKON did not receive sufficient notice of the damages hearing,
  we remanded the matter to the circuit court for a new hearing on damages.Â  McCall
    v. IKON, 363 S.C. 646, 611 S.E.2d 315 (Ct. App. 2005). 
During this hearing, the parties presented evidence that in
  November 2001, McCall signed an agreement with IKON for an â€œEnterprise Training Pass,â€ entitling him to twelve months of unlimited course attendance at any
  scheduled IKON public systems training course in certain specified areas,
  including Microsoft, Novell and Lotus.Â  McCall entered the course of study with
  the goal of becoming a Microsoft Certified Systems Engineer, and paid IKON
  tuition of $12,500.Â  At that time, McCall held a Bachelorâ€™s degree in biology,
  as well as a Masterâ€™s degree in forestry, and had worked for a number of years
  in the forestry related area.
In order to become a certified Microsoft Systems Engineer, McCall
  needed to pass tests in seven different courses that were administered by an
  independent agency.Â  McCall began attending IKON classes on November 19, 2001,
  and completed three courses.Â  He subsequently passed two of the seven required
  tests.Â  However, IKON sold the company to CESC in the last quarter of 2001 and,
  thereafter, on January 2, 2002, CESC chose to cease operating in the Greenville area.
After learning of the closing, McCall went to the training
  facility and requested a refund of $12,500.Â  On January 9, 2002, McCall filed
  the present breach of contract action, against IKON and CESC.Â  McCall,
  363 S.C. at 650, 611 S.E.2d at 316.Â Â  On January 24, 2002, Clint Babcock sent
  McCall an e-mail with a document attached, requesting McCall sign and return
  the form to â€œcesc/IKON Educationâ€ if he agreed to the terms.Â  The document
  offered a refund to McCall in exchange for McCall signing a release.[1]Â  McCall testified he did not consider
  the document an offer, â€œbecause [he] never saw the check.â€
Thereafter, McCall began looking for a job and ultimately went to
  work for Schneider Tree Care as a consulting arborist in July 2002, where he
  earned approximately $35,000 a year.Â  He continued his employment with
  Schneider until June 2004, at which time McCall left that job in order to
  pursue a Ph.D. in horticulture at Clemson University.Â  McCall stated he worked
  as a graduate assistant while pursuing that degree, earning about $7,500,
  however, the program was discontinued within six months due to lack of research
  funding and McCallâ€™s position was terminated.[2]Â 
  On March 21, 2005, McCall began work with the North Carolina Forest Service,
  earning $33,942 a year.Â  In May 2003, during the time he was working at
  Schneiderâ€™s and well before he entered the Ph.D. program, McCall received a
  settlement of $25,000 from CESC. [3]
McCall admitted that in January 2002, he was aware of two or three
  other courses available in the area that were sufficient for him to obtain the
  certification he sought and were less expensive.Â  He further agreed that after
  CESC stopped providing training in the area in January 2002, he did not enroll
  in any of the other available computer classes.Â  McCall claimed, however, that
  his lack of funds, created by the actions of IKON, kept him out of a career in
  computers.Â  He asserted at trial that he was entitled to damages of $12,500
  plus prejudgment interest for the tuition he paid, lost wages for a period of
  six months, and interest of six percent incurred on the money borrowed for the
  tuition. 
McCall further presented Dr. Charles Alford as an expert witness
  in economics and business valuation.[4]Â 
  Dr. Alford testified he computed the present value difference between a
  projection of lifetime earnings McCall would have received had he entered a
  career in the computer field as opposed to a projection of lifetime earnings in
  the forestry field in which McCall was currently working.Â  Dr. Alford compared
  McCallâ€™s current wages of $33,942 in forestry and his projected future earnings
  were he to stay with his current job against data from a South Carolina
  Occupational Employment and Wage report indicating the projected income of
  someone working as a systems administrator in the computer field at the time
  McCall would have finished the IKON program, along with his projected future
  income in that field.Â  He opined that if McCall had become a computer systems
  engineer, he would receive $340,406 more in lifetime income and fringe benefits
  than he would if he remained a forester.
On cross-examination, Dr. Alford admitted he was not a vocational
  expert and was not qualified to determine employability.Â  He testified he based
  his determination on projections for a network and systems administrator
  because McCall had identified that as his career objective, but agreed McCall
  had no employment history in the computer field and acknowledged he was not
  willing to offer testimony that McCall could have been employed as such.Â  Dr.
  Alford also agreed his figures did not include starting McCall out at projected
  entry level earnings for a forester because he knew McCallâ€™s actual earnings at
  that time.Â  He further admitted he did not take into account in the forestry
  earnings projection that McCall had years of experience as well as a Masterâ€™s
  degree in forestry.Â  He consistently stated that if the court were to determine
  McCall did not earn as much as he could have earned in the forestry field, the
  figures should be adjusted or â€œthe whole thing [should] be set aside.â€
Dr. Benson Hecker testified on behalf of IKON as an expert in the
  area of vocational evaluation.Â  Dr. Hecker testified, as a vocational
  evaluation specialist, he looked at a personâ€™s age, education, vocational
  background and skills, along with the job market to â€œput together an opinion
  regarding a personâ€™s capacity to earn money,â€ to aid the court in determining a
  personâ€™s employability and salary levels.Â  After reviewing information on
  McCall relative to these factors, as well as obtaining information from The
  U.S. Department of Labor Statistics showing State Occupation and Employment
  Wage Estimates for South Carolina, and further contacting Clemson University
  with regard to salary levels, Dr. Hecker was of the opinion that McCall would
  suffer no loss of earning capacity as a result of the cancellation of the
  computer program.Â  
In reaching his conclusion, Dr. Hecker opined McCall could have
  entered the forestry field in North Carolina at the mean salary level rather
  than at entry level, and determined the appropriate figure to use for
  determining McCallâ€™s expected salary in forestry was the mean salary level of
  between $51,000 and $52,000 based on McCallâ€™s experience and background.Â  Dr.
  Hecker further testified it was his opinion McCallâ€™s failure to take the refund
  offered in January 2002 delayed his completion of a program and continuation of
  his education, and further delayed his entry into the job market.Â  Had McCall
  been dedicated to entering the computer field, he reasonably would have
  accepted the offer and continued his education.Â  As a result, there would be no
  loss.Â  Additionally, Dr. Hecker noted McCallâ€™s receipt of the $25,000
  settlement proceeds in May 2003 and his failure to continue his education in
  the computer field at that time indicated McCallâ€™s desire to work in the
  forestry industry instead of the computer field.Â  It was his opinion that the
  best occupational career path for McCall was, and continued to be, in the
  forestry field.Â  According to Dr. Hecker, Dr. Alfordâ€™s present value
  calculations were of no import because he was of the opinion McCall suffered
  â€œno loss of earning, no loss of wages.â€
IKON also presented the testimony of Peter Tiffany, a Certified
  Public Accountant.Â  Mr. Tiffany was offered and qualified as an expert in the
  area of computation of present values.Â  Given the $52,000 mean salary figure
  for foresters in Dr. Heckerâ€™s report, Mr. Tiffany used the same inflation
  rates, growth rates and discount rates as Dr. Alford used in his analysis to
  project present value and determined, using the same assumption as Dr. Alford
  for the projected present value of earnings in the computer field, that the
  projected earnings in the forestry industry would be greater than those in the
  computer industry, resulting in no loss of earning capacity for McCall.Â  Mr.
  Tiffany likewise performed the same calculations based on an average $40,000
  starting salary range for foresters, taken from Dr. Heckerâ€™s report indicating
  such starting range is between $35,000 and $45,000, as well as on a mean salary
  range of $49,538 taken from an exhibit from Dr. Alfordâ€™s deposition.Â  In both
  cases, the present values of the forestry earnings compared to the computer
  earnings resulted in a negative net result, showing no loss of earnings in the
  forestry field compared to the computer industry.
Based on the evidence presented, the circuit court found McCall
  was entitled to damages in the amount of $24,379.33.Â  The court held the
  testimony of IKONâ€™s witnesses was more reliable, credible, and persuasive, and
  that Dr. Alfordâ€™s opinion was not â€œreliable or probative on the issue of
  damages.â€Â  The court noted, although McCall testified of his desire to pursue a
  career in computers, there was little evidence to support this assertion, the
  vast majority of McCallâ€™s education and employment was in forestry related
  fields, and McCallâ€™s â€œforay in the computer fieldâ€ only lasted for approximately
  one month.Â  The court further considered that Dr. Alford, who admitted he is
  not a vocational expert, based his opinion as to McCallâ€™s vocational aptitude
  entirely upon McCallâ€™s â€œbeliefs as to his desires,â€ and based his calculations
  of lost earnings in the computer field on a position McCall was merely â€œhoping
  to obtain.â€Â  Because of the improper foundation on which Dr. Alford based his
  opinion as to the $340,406 difference in projected lifetime earnings between
  the two fields, the circuit court determined Dr. Alfordâ€™s testimony did not
  provide persuasive evidence of McCallâ€™s loss of earnings or loss of earning
  capacity.
On the other hand, the court found Dr. Hecker, who is a vocational
  expert, considered the fact that comparable programs for computer study were
  available to McCall both in January 2002 when he was offered a refund, and May
  2003 when he received the $25,000 settlement, yet McCall chose not to pursue
  any training in the computer field.Â  Thus, it was reasonable to assume McCallâ€™s
  interests actually rested in the forestry field.Â  The court agreed with Dr.
  Hecker that McCallâ€™s best vocational path was in the forestry related field and
  it would therefore be speculative to make a mathematical comparison of
  projected incomes between the computer and forestry fields.Â  The court further
  found, however, even if the mathematical comparison is analyzed, the evidence
  confirms McCall suffered no loss of earnings or earning capacity.Â  Finding the
  main difference between the partiesâ€™ calculations to arise from the use of the
  starting salary in the forestry field, the court recognized Dr. Alford failed
  to consider McCallâ€™s educational or employment background in the forestry
  field.
As to the loss of earnings McCall sought from January 2002 through
  2005, the court found McCall could have returned to the workforce after CESC
  cancelled the program instead of waiting seven months to obtain employment.Â 
  Additionally, McCall could have continued with his job as an arborist making in
  excess of $35,000 a year, but voluntarily quit that job and, thereafter, did
  not work for approximately one year before taking the North Carolina forestry
  job.Â  Accordingly, the trial court determined McCall was, â€œfor the most part,
  voluntarily unemployed or underemployed.â€Â  The court further found McCallâ€™s
  claim for lost wages of $12,157 between January 2002 and July 2002 was the
  result of McCallâ€™s own decision to not be employed during that time period.Â 
  The circuit court also noted, although McCall sought $1,012.70 in interest he
  allegedly paid his mother on a $12,500 note he signed for a loan on the
  tuition, McCall ultimately admitted that he did not, in fact, pay any interest
  on the note.Â  Finally, the trial court found McCallâ€™s testimony regarding his
  reasons for failure to use the offered refund or settlement money to enroll in
  computer classes to lack credibility.Â  The court thus determined McCall failed
  to mitigate any alleged damages by refusing to take available funds and pursue
  a career path in computers, and IKON should not be held responsible for any
  alleged economic loss due to McCallâ€™s decisions.
The court concluded McCallâ€™s claim for loss of future earnings and
  earning capacity were based wholly on speculation or conjecture and McCall
  failed to establish his claim for the same with reasonable certainty.Â  It
  further held McCall failed to mitigate any such alleged damages resulting from
  the breach.Â  However, the court determined McCall was entitled to damages for
  the tuition paid along with a reasonable amount for lost wages, resulting in a
  total sum of $24,379.33.Â  The circuit court held, in light of the settlement
  money McCall received from CESC, IKON was entitled to a credit in the amount of
  $25,000, and the judgment was therefore to be marked satisfied.
ISSUES
1.Â 
  Did the trial court improperly calculate McCallâ€™s damages?
2.Â  Did the trial
  court err in its admission and interpretation of the January 24, 2002 e-mail
  sent to McCall?
3.Â  Were the
  damages of McCall â€œproperly mitigated?â€
4.Â  Did the trial
  court err in requesting additional evidence of an asset purchase agreement
  between IKON and CESC after the conclusion of the damages hearing?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  action for breach of contract seeking money damages is an action at law.Â  Eldeco,
    Inc. v. Charleston County Sch. Dist., 372 S.C. 470, 476, 642 S.E.2d 726,
  729 (2007).Â  On appeal of an action at law tried without a jury, the findings
  of fact of the trial court will not be disturbed unless found to be without
  evidence which reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  Townes
    Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775
  (1976).Â  â€œStated another way,Â  the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact will not be
  disturbed on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or unless it
  clearly appears the findings were influenced or controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court St., LLC, 369 S.C. 121, 127,
  631 S.E.2d 252, 255 (2006).Â  In such a case, the trial courtâ€™s findings are
  equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action. Â Id.Â  Further, questions
  concerning credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence are exclusively
  for the trial court. Â Ward v. West Oil Co., 379 S.C. 225, 238, 665
  S.E.2d 618, 625 (Ct. App. 2008).
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. Calculation of Damages
On
  appeal, McCall first contends the circuit court improperly calculated his
  damages.Â  He maintains he is entitled to damages of $12,500 for the tuition,
  $5,397.80 in prejudgment interest on the tuition, $12,157 in lost wages from
  January 4, 2002 through July 13, 2002, and a wage differential through at least
  June 1, 2004 of $32,164 for a total minimum in damages of $62,218.80.Â  McCall
  also argues the court erroneously refused to consider the testimony of Dr.
  Alford based on the fact Dr. Alford was not a vocational expert, asserting Dr.
  Alford never addressed any vocational issues.Â  McCall further asserts IKONâ€™s
  witness used â€œthe wrong category of earningsâ€ by assuming McCallâ€™s salary in
  forestry would be $52,000 when his actual salary in that field was only $34,000.
We
  find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s findings regarding Dr. Alford and its
  determination that McCall suffered no loss of earning capacity.Â  There is more
  than sufficient evidence of record to support the courtâ€™s findings that
  McCallâ€™s best vocational path was in the forestry field. The record further
  supports the courtâ€™s determination that, even in performing a mathematical
  comparison between the forestry and computer fields, McCall still suffered no
  loss.Â  The court did not, as McCall argues, refuse to consider the testimony of
  Dr. Alford.Â  Rather, the court considered his testimony, but concluded it did
  not provide persuasive evidence of McCallâ€™s loss of earning capacity and found
  that IKONâ€™s witnesses were more reliable, credible and persuasive.Â  As noted,
  in an action at law sitting without a jury, the trial courtâ€™s findings are
  equivalent to that of a jury, and questions concerning credibility and the
  weight to be afforded evidence lie with the trial court.Â Â  
Further,
  McCall does not argue on appeal that the circuit courtâ€™s award of damages is
  unsupported by the evidence.Â  Nor does McCall assert the trial court made a
  mathematical error in computation of the damages.[5]Â 
  As to the specific figures to which McCall asserts he is entitled, he provides
  this court with no support for them in the record.Â  In short, McCall summarily
  asserts he is entitled to these amounts without showing why the circuit courtâ€™s
  calculation of damages was erroneous or how McCallâ€™s figures are supported by
  the evidence. Â See Weaver v. Recreation Dist., 328 S.C. 83, 88,
  492 S.E.2d 79, 82 (1997); Ehlke v. Nemec Constr. Co., 298 S.C. 477, 481,
  381 S.E.2d 508, 510 (Ct. App. 1989) (noting an appealed order comes to the appellate
  court with a presumption of correctness and the burden is on appellant to
  demonstrate reversible error); See also Harris v. Campbell,
  293 S.C. 85, 87, 358 S.E.2d 719, 720 (Ct. App. 1987) (noting our court is â€œobliged
  to reverse when error is called to our attention, but we are not in the
  business of figuring out on our own whether error existsâ€).Â  Accordingly, we
  find McCall has failed to meet his burden of demonstrating reversible error.
B.Â 
  Error in Admission and Interpretation of E-mail
McCall
  next contends the circuit court erred in admitting into evidence the e-mail
  sent by Clint Babcock to McCall on January 24, 2002 because McCall was seeking
  damages from IKON and the e-mail involved negotiations between him and CESC,
  not him and IKON.Â  He further contends the court erred in interpreting the
  e-mail as an offer when it was only an invitation to negotiate.Â  Finally,
  McCall claims there was no showing that the e-mail contained a â€œfair and
  equitableâ€ proposal, especially in light of the circuit courtâ€™s subsequent
  award of over twice that amount.Â  We find no error.
At
  the damages hearing, McCall objected to the admission of the e-mail because
  â€œthis offer was not from IKON . . . [but] was from another party altogether.â€Â 
  When asked whether the basis of his objection was relevance, McCallâ€™s attorney
  stated it was, and that he was â€œobjecting to this as being relevant.â€Â  Counsel
  for IKON countered that Babcock worked for IKON at the time and that the e-mail
  denotes â€œcesc/IKON Education.â€Â  IKON further argued the document was relevant
  as to the issue of McCallâ€™s failure to mitigate his damages.
The
  admission or exclusion of evidence is addressed to the sound discretion of the
  trial judge, whose decision will not be overturned absent an abuse of
  discretion.Â  Fields v. J. Haynes Waters Builders, Inc., 376 S.C. 545, 567,
  658 S.E.2d 80, 92 (2008).Â  Generally, all relevant evidence is admissible.Â 
  Rule 402, SCRE.Â  Evidence is relevant if it has any tendency to make the
  existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action
  more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.Â  Rule
  401, SCRE. Â Â 
Here,
  McCallâ€™s sole objection raised to admission of the e-mail at the damages
  hearing was that it was not relevant because it was an â€œofferâ€ from another
  party and not from IKON.Â  Thus, this is the only argument on this issue
  preserved for review.Â  SeeÂ  Durham v. Vinson, 360 S.C. 639,
  653-54, 602 S.E.2d 760, 767 (2004) (holding to preserve an issue for appellate
  review, the issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by trial court, and a
  party may not argue one ground for objection at trial and another ground on
  appeal). Â McCall admitted at
  the hearing that he was aware of two or three other courses available in the
  area in January 2002 that were sufficient for him to obtain the certification
  he sought and were less expensive, yet he did not enroll in any of the other
  available computer classes, claiming a lack of funds created by the actions of
  IKON.Â  Whether it came from IKON or from the entity that acquired IKON, the
  e-mail offer of a refund only twenty-two days after CESC ceased providing
  classes in the Greenville area is clearly relevant to whether McCall suffered
  from a lack of funds that prohibited him from enrollment in the comparable
  computer classes and whether McCall attempted to mitigate his alleged damages.Â 
  Accordingly, we find no error.
C.Â  Mitigation of Damages
McCall next argues there is evidence he mitigated his damages.Â  He
  asserts that he quickly sought employment after the computer classes were
  cancelled, obtaining a job at Schneider after a short period of time, and
  further sought to mitigate his damages by entering the Ph.D. program, but these
  efforts failed because Clemson University was unable to fund the program.Â 
  McCall argues the circuit courtâ€™s finding that he should have used the
  settlement proceeds to enroll into another local computer program amounted to
  speculation and there was no evidence of any local computer programs which
  would enable him to obtain Microsoft Certified Systems Engineer certification.Â 
  He maintains â€œ[t]here is ample evidence that [he] acted reasonably in regard to
  his decision to use his forestry education once he had been deprived of his
  opportunity to pursue a certified Microsoft Systems Engineer career.â€
The bulk of the damages sought by McCall center around his claim
  of loss of earning capacity based on the failure of IKON to provide the agreed
  to computer training and McCallâ€™s lack of available funds to continue down a
  computer career path.Â  The circuit court found McCallâ€™s explanation for his
  failure to accept the refund offer in January 2002, because he â€œnever saw a
  check,â€ to lack credibility.Â  The court further found McCallâ€™s testimony that
  it would have been irresponsible for him to quit his job with Schneider to go
  back to school after receiving the CESC settlement money because he had a son
  to care for at that time was also not credible in light of the fact that McCall
  ultimately quit this job to go back to school for his Ph.D. less than two
  months after his son was born.Â  The court determined McCall had funds available
  to pursue his education in computers, but elected not to do so.Â  Accordingly,
  the court held McCall failed to mitigate his damages. 
There is evidence of record that in January 2002, McCall was
  offered a refund of the tuition and, though he was aware of two or three other
  less expensive courses available in the area that were sufficient for him to
  obtain the certification he sought, he failed to enroll in any of these other
  available computer classes.Â  Further, there is evidence that McCall received a
  settlement of twice the tuition amount from CESC in May 2003, and therefore had
  funds available with which he could have enrolled in computer classes at that
  time.Â  As noted, questions of credibility and the weight to be accorded
  evidence are exclusively with the trial court.Â  There is more than sufficient
  evidence of record that reasonably
  supports the circuit courtâ€™s findings in this regard.
McCall
  further asserts the trial court improperly used the settlement proceeds twice
  because it used the proceeds â€œas a mitigating factor to reduce [McCallâ€™s]
  damagesâ€ and then used the settlement proceeds â€œas a direct set-off.â€Â  He
  asserts the proceeds could be used as a mitigating factor or an off-set, but
  not both.Â  We do not follow McCallâ€™s logic.Â  McCall cites no law or rule that
  prohibits the circuit court from considering receipt of the settlement money as
  a factor in determining mitigation and as a set-off against his total damages.Â 
  Further, the court did not use the settlement proceeds to reduce McCallâ€™s damages.Â  Rather, the court simply considered McCallâ€™s failure to use
  the available settlement proceeds as one of the factors in determining whether
  he mitigated his alleged damages.Â  Thereafter, the court found McCall suffered
  total damages of $24,379.33 and concluded IKON was entitled to a credit of the
  $25,000 paid by CESC against its judgment pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann.
  Section 32-9-10 et seq., a determination that, in and of itself, McCall
  does not challenge. Â There is simply no logical reason the court could not both
  consider the availability of these funds, paid by IKONâ€™s successor entity, in
  determining the ultimate damages to which McCall was entitled and award IKON a
  credit for the settlement funds paid toward those damages.
D.Â 
  Evidence of an Asset Purchase Agreement
Finally,
  McCall argues the circuit court erred in asking for the additional evidence of
  a copy of the asset purchase agreement between IKON and CESC following the
  conclusion of the damages hearing.Â  He argues there was no testimony presented
  concerning the document, he was not afforded an opportunity to address this
  document, and no issue concerning this document was raised before the court.
There
  is no asset purchase agreement document in the record before this court.Â 
  Further, there is nothing in the record to show the circuit court asked for
  such a document, nor any indication McCall objected to the document as he
  claims.Â  Neither is there any evidence the circuit court considered such a document
  in its ruling.Â  In short, the record is devoid of any evidence whatsoever
  concerning the document of which McCall complains.Â  As the appellant, McCall bears
  the burden of providing this court with a record sufficient to allow appellate
  review.Â  See Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 606, 616, 533
  S.E.2d 886, 891 (2000) (noting the appellant has the burden of presenting an
  adequate record on appeal); see also Rule 210(h), SCACR (â€œExcept
  as provided by Rule 212 and Rule 208(b)(1)(C) and (2), the appellate court will
  not consider any fact which does not appear in the Record on Appeal.â€).Â  Because
  McCall did not provide this court with an adequate record to consider this
  argument, we affirm the trial court on this issue as well.
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, the trial courtâ€™s order finding McCall entitled to
  damages of $24,379.33 on his breach of contract action against IKON is
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON
  and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] Curiously, while the parties and the circuit
  court refer to this document as an offer to refund $10,416.66, a reading of the
  attachment in the record indicates, although CESC believed it was only required
  to refund McCall the pro-rata amount of $10,416.66, CESC would provide him â€œa
  full refund of ($12,500) as an exception to [their] established policy.â€
[2] There is also evidence of record which suggests
  McCallâ€™s actual earnings for the year 2004 were only $4,964, and were thus less
  than the $7,500 he claimed to have made that year as a graduate assistant.
[3] McCall testified he used this money to pay his mother
  the $12,500 he borrowed for the tuition and the rest was used to pay off two
  car loans.Â  McCall admitted he did not pay interest on the loan from his
  mother.
[4] IKON
  questioned Dr. Alfordâ€™s qualification and his testimony regarding McCallâ€™s loss
  of earning capacity based upon the fact Dr. Alford was not a vocational expert,
  but the circuit court qualified Dr. Alford as requested and allowed the
  evidence, finding it was an issue which could be explored on cross-examination.
[5]Additionally, even if McCall contends the trial court
  made a mathematical computation error, it was incumbent upon McCall to raise
  the issue by way of a Rule 59 or 60, SCRCP motion to preserve the matter on
  appeal.Â  See Revis v. Barrett, 321 S.C. 206, 210, 467 S.E.2d 460,
  463 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding issue was not preserved on appeal where appellants
  never filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment to clarify the order
  pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP, nor seek clarification pursuant to Rule 60(a), SCRCP
  and, issue was therefore not raised to and ruled upon by the trial court).

title: Pee Dee Stores v. Doyle
description: Appellant Billy W. Huggins, d/b/a Huggins Farm Service (Huggins), brought this action, seeking review of an order granting Pee Dee Stores, Inc.â€™s (Pee Dee Stores) summary judgment motion and motion to compel settlement based on a Settlement Agreement.  Huggins asserts that the Settlement Agreement was intended to resolve only the landlord/tenant claims and that his civil conspiracy and unfair trade practices claims against both Pee Dee Stores and Third-Party Defendant Helena Chemical Company (Helena) survived the Settlement Agreement.  As such, Huggins alleges that summary judgment was improper because a genuine issue of material fact exists as to whether the parties to the Settlement Agreement intended to extinguish Hugginsâ€™ claims against Pee Dee Stores and Helena.  The Court of Appeals held that summary judgment was improper and reversed the circuit court's judgment.
