THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Pee Dee Stores, Inc., Plaintiff,
				v.
				Carolyn H. Doyle, d/b/a Pee Dee Farms Company, and Billy
      W. Huggins, individually and d/b/a Huggins Farm Service, Inc., Defendants,
				of Whom Carolyn H. Doyle, d/b/a Pee Dee Farms Company,
      and Billy W. Huggins, individually and d/b/a Huggins Farm Service, Inc. are
      the, Third-Party
      Plaintiffs,
				v.
				Helena Chemical Company, Third-Party
      Defendant.
				Pee Dee Stores, Inc., Plaintiff,
				v.
				Carolyn H. Doyle, d/b/a Pee Dee Farms Company, Defendant,
      of Whom Carolyn H. Doyle, d/b/a Pee Dee Farms Company is the,
				Third-Party Plaintiff,
				v.
				Helena Chemical Company, Third-Party
      Defendant,
				of Whom Carolyn
      H. Doyle, d/b/a Pee Dee Farms Company, and Billy W. Huggins, individually and
      d/b/a Huggins Farm Service, Inc. are the Appellants
				and 
				Pee Dee Stores,
          Inc., and Helena Chemical Company are the Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4467
Submitted October 8, 2008 â€“ Filed December
  12, 2008
Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled
  January 29, 2009Â Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Amanda A. Bailey, Esquire, and Henrietta
  U. Golding, Esquire, of Myrtle Beach; for Appellant.
				Douglas M. Zayicek, Esquire, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
			
		
	

GEATHERS, J.: Appellant Billy W. Huggins, d/b/a Huggins Farm Service (Huggins), seeks review of an order granting Pee Dee
  Stores, Inc.â€™s (Pee Dee Stores) summary judgment motion and motion to compel settlement
  based on a Settlement Agreement.Â  Huggins asserts that the Settlement Agreement
  was intended to resolve only the landlord/tenant claims and that his civil
  conspiracy and unfair trade practices claims against both Pee Dee Stores and Third-Party
  Defendant Helena Chemical Company (Helena) survived the Settlement Agreement.Â  As
  such, Huggins alleges that summary judgment was improper because a genuine
  issue of material fact exists as to whether the parties to the Settlement
  Agreement intended to extinguish Hugginsâ€™ claims against Pee Dee Stores and
  Helena.Â  We reverse. Â 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Pee Dee Stores and Paul E. Doyle, deceased husband
  of Defendant Carolyn Doyle,[1] d/b/a Pee Dee Farms Company (Doyle), entered into a five-year commercial lease agreement
  that commenced on March 1, 2000 and was to terminate on February 28, 2005.Â  Doyle
  used the leased premises to operate a convenience store, gas station, and farm
  supply retail store.Â  The lease agreement afforded Doyle an option to renew the
  lease by providing written notice to Pee Dee Stores by December 1, 2004.Â  During
  the lease term, and pursuant to an agreement with Doyle in late 2003, Huggins
  began selling farm supplies out of the leased premises in his capacity as a
  commissioned agent for Helena.[2] 

Prior to the termination of the lease, Pee Dee
  Stores represented to Doyle that the lease term would be extended to allow
  Doyle until December 1, 2005 to consider the option to renew.Â  In addition, Helena represented to Huggins that it intended to purchase Hugginsâ€™ farm supply business
  with all of the attached goodwill.Â  At that time, Huggins, Doyle, and Helena
  began negotiations.Â  Subsequently, and prior to the December 1, 2005 deadline,
  Doyle notified Pee Dee Stores in writing of her intention to exercise the option
  to renew the lease.Â  Pee Dee Stores informed Doyle that she could not exercise
  the option to renew and asked her to vacate the store.Â  
Pee Dee Stores filed an ejectment action against
  Doyle in magistrate court, asserting a violation of the lease as well as its expiration
  as grounds for ejectment.[3]Â 
  Doyle answered the complaint by denying the material allegations and sought a
  declaratory judgment that she was the legal tenant under the lease and had
  properly exercised the option to renew.Â  In addition, Pee Dee Stores later
  filed a separate action for breach of contract against Doyle and Huggins.Â  The
  complaint also alleged interference with contractual relations and fraud, among
  other claims.Â  
In response to both the ejectment and breach of
  contract actions, Doyle and Huggins counterclaimed against Pee Dee Stores seeking
  monetary damages for issues related to the landlord/tenant relationship.Â 
  Further, the parties asserted in a Third-Party Complaint against Helena causes of action for negligent misrepresentation, unfair trade practices, civil
  conspiracy, promissory estoppel, interference with a contract, and interference
  with a prospective contract.Â  These causes of action were based upon an alleged
  conspiracy between Helena and Pee Dee Stores to oust Doyle and Huggins from the
  property in order to enable Helena to rent the leased premises and take over both
  partiesâ€™ business goodwill without compensation. Â 
Subsequently, Doyle and Huggins brought a motion
  to consolidate the ejectment and breach of contract actions.Â  The trial court
  denied the motion to consolidate, ordering the parties to resolve the issues
  related to the ejectment action first, after which discovery and trial of the
  remaining issues would occur.Â  
While both actions were pending, Pee Dee Stores,
  Doyle, and Huggins entered into a Settlement Agreement, which was subtitled as â€œRelating
  Only to All Landlord/Tenant Issues.â€Â  The record does not indicate which party
  drafted the Settlement Agreement.Â  All three parties signed the Settlement
  Agreement.Â  The pertinent provisions of the Settlement Agreement are as
  follows:

	
		
			7.  
			The parties shall forever release each other from all claims 
			and/or issues, whenever arising, with each agreeing they will never 
			sue or involve each other in any litigation involving the premises, 
			the store, any business on the premises, and/or the relationship 
			between the Parties, as follows: (1) the Parties agree this is a full
    and complete release of all claims known and unknown, between Pee Dee
      Stores, Inc. and Carolyn Doyle, d/b/a Pee Dee Farms Company; and (2) the Parties agree this is a full and complete release of all landlord/tenant
        claims and issues, known or unknown, between the Parties. 
 
		
		
			8. 
			 Nothing in this
  agreement shall be construed as in any way effecting [sic] the rights of Billy
  W. Huggins and/or Huggins Farm Service, Inc. to assert claims against Helena
  Chemical Company.Â  Nothing in this agreement shall be construed as in
    any way effecting [sic] the rights of Billy W. Huggins and/or Huggins Farm
    Service, Inc. to assert claims against Pee Dee Stores, Inc. for claims other
    than the landlord/tenant claims.Â  Nothing herein shall be construed as a
      relinquishment, waiver, discharge or release of any claims by Billy W.
  Huggins and/or Huggins Farm Services, Inc. against Pee Dee Stores, Inc., for
    any claims other than the landlord/tenant claims. 
 
		
		
			 
			. .
  . Â 
 
		
		
			10. 
			Pee Dee Stores, Inc. and Carolyn Doyle d/b/a Pee Dee 
			Farms Company agree to dismiss all claims against each other, with 
			prejudice, and Pee Dee Stores, Inc. and Billy W. Huggins, 
			individually and Huggins Farm Service, Inc., agree to dismiss only the landlord/tenant claims with prejudice.Â Â  
			
		
	


(emphasis added). 

Pee Dee Stores later moved to
  enforce the Settlement Agreement. Subsequently, Doyle and Huggins moved to
  amend their pleadings to remove all of the landlord/tenant claims against Pee
  Dee Stores that were resolved by the Settlement Agreement, including the declaratory
  judgment, breach of lease, and negligent misrepresentation claims.Â  Huggins proposed
  to leave intact the civil conspiracy and unfair trade practices claims against Pee
  Dee Stores and Helena.Â  Pee Dee Stores also moved to amend its pleadings to
  reflect the Settlement Agreement and moved for summary judgment.
At the hearing on the various
  motions, counsel for Pee Dee Stores, Doyle, and Huggins acknowledged that
  settlement was reached regarding the ejectment action and that the terms were
  set forth in the Settlement Agreement.Â  The trial court granted Pee Dee Storesâ€™
  motion to compel settlement and summary judgment motion, finding the pleadings indicated
  that all allegations involved landlord/tenant claims and issues â€œinvolving the
  premises, the store, any business on the premises, and/or the relationship
  between the Parties[,]â€ and as such were resolved by the Settlement Agreement.Â 
  Huggins now appeals. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion,
  this Court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule
  56(c), SCRCP, which provides that summary judgment is appropriate only when
  there is no genuine issue of material fact and the movant is entitled to
  judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty, Inc. v.
    Gibson Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005) (when
  reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies
  the same standard of review as the trial court).Â  Summary judgment should be granted when plain,
  palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ.Â  Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App.
  2004).Â  However, summary judgment is not appropriate when further inquiry into
  the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of law.Â  Tupper
    v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  
In determining whether any triable issues of fact
  exist, the evidence and all inferences must be viewed in the light most
  favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co.,
  364 S.C. 222, 227, 612 S.E.2d 719, 722 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Thus, the appellate
  court reviews all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from
  the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Willis v.
    Wu, 362 S.C. 146, 151, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004).Â  If evidentiary facts are not disputed, but the
  conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them are, summary judgment should be
  denied.Â  Baugus v. Wessinger, 303 S.C. 412, 415, 401 S.E.2d 169, 171
  (1991).Â  Further, â€œ[t]he purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition
  of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v.
    Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001) (internal citations
  omitted).
Summary judgment is improper when there is an issue as
  to the construction of a written contract and the contract is ambiguous because
  the intent of the parties cannot be gathered from the four corners of the
  instrument.Â  Gilliland v. Elmwood Prop., 301 S.C. 295, 299, 391 S.E.2d
  577, 579 (1990) (internal citations omitted);Â  HK New Plan Exch. Prop. Owner
    I, LLC v. Coker, 375 S.C. 18, 23, 649 S.E.2d 181, 184 (Ct. App. 2007);Â  Bishop
      v. Benson, 297 S.C. 14, 17, 374 S.E.2d 517, 518-19 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The
  court is without authority to consider partiesâ€™ secret intentions, and
  therefore words cannot be read into a contract to impart an intent unexpressed
  when the contract was executed.Â  Blakely v. Rabon, 266 S.C. 68, 73, 221
  S.E.2d 767, 769 (1976).Â  Construction of an ambiguous contract is a question of
  fact to be decided by the trier of fact.Â  Soil Remediation Co. v. Nu-Way
    Envtl., Inc., 325 S.C. 231, 234, 482 S.E.2d 554, 555 (1997); Lacke v.
      Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 309, 608 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 2005). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Huggins asserts the trial court erred in granting Pee
  Dee Storesâ€™ summary judgment motion and motion to compel settlement because a genuine
  issue of material fact exists as to whether the parties to the Settlement
  Agreement intended to dismiss Hugginsâ€™ unfair trade practices and civil
  conspiracy claims against Helena and Pee Dee Stores.Â  We agree. 
A.  Settlement Agreement Viewed as a Contract
In South Carolina jurisprudence, settlement agreements are
  viewed as contracts.Â  Harris-Jenkins v. Nissan Car Mart, Inc., 348 S.C.
  171, 177, 557 S.E.2d 708, 711 (Ct. App. 2001); see also Pruitt v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 343 S.C. 335, 339, 540
  S.E.2d 843, 845 (2001) (enforcement of the terms of a settlement agreement is a
  matter of contract law); Ecclesiastes Prod. Ministries v. Outparcel Assoc.,
    LLC, 374 S.C. 483, 497, 649 S.E.2d 494, 501 (Ct. App. 2007) (a release
  agreement is a contract and contract principles of law should be used to determine
  what the parties intended); Mattox v. Cassady, 289 S.C. 57, 61, 344
  S.E.2d 620, 622 (Ct. App. 1986) (applying the general rules of contract
  construction to a settlement agreement).Â  
General contract principles are applied in the construction
  of a settlement agreement because, as stated above, a settlement agreement is a
  contract.Â  Summary judgment is not appropriate if a contract is ambiguous.Â 
  Thus, the initial determination for a court seeking to ascertain whether a
  grant of summary judgment based on a settlement agreementâ€™s interpretation is
  proper is whether the agreement is ambiguous.Â  See Soil Remediation
    Co. v. Nu-Way Envtl., Inc., 325 S.C. at 234, 482 S.E.2d at 555. 
B.  Ambiguity in a Contract
Whether the language of a contract is ambiguous is a question
  of law for the court.Â  Auten v. Snipes, 370 S.C. 664, 669, 636 S.E.2d
  644, 646 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  A contract is ambiguous when the terms of the
  contract are reasonably susceptible to more than one interpretation.Â  South Carolina Dept. of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617,
  623, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001); Davis v. Davis, 372 S.C. 64, 76,
  641 S.E.2d 446, 452 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The uncertainty in interpretation can
  arise from the words of the instrument, or in the application of the words to
  the object they describe.Â  Hann v. Carolina Cas. Inc. Co., 252 S.C. 518,
  524, 167 S.E.2d 420, 422 (1969).Â  Whether a contract is ambiguous must be
  determined from the entire contract and not from any isolated clause of the
  agreement.Â  Farr v. Duke Power Co., 265 S.C. 356, 362, 218 S.E.2d 431,
  433 (1975). Â 

In the matter presently before the Court, an ambiguity
  exists in the Settlement Agreement regarding the definition and scope of
  â€œlandlord/tenant claims.â€ The term â€œlandlord/tenant claimsâ€ is reasonably
  susceptible to more than one interpretation, and therefore, summary judgment was
  inappropriate. Â 
The trial court based its summary judgment ruling on
  the conclusion that all allegations in both the ejectment and breach of
  contract actions involved landlord/tenant claims, and issues â€œinvolving the
  premises, the store, any business on the premises, and/or the relationship
  between the Parties[,]â€ and as such were resolved by the Settlement Agreement.Â 
  This constituted error because there was a genuine issue of material fact as to
  the meaning and scope of â€œlandlord/tenant claims,â€ and the partiesâ€™ intentions
  as to which claims survived the Settlement Agreement differed, thus precluding
  summary judgment in favor of Pee Dee Stores. 
The language of the Settlement Agreement is clear that
  all landlord/tenant claims were to be resolved by the Settlement Agreement.Â  In
  fact, the title of the Agreement itself evinces the intent to resolve only all
  landlord/tenant issues.Â  It reads in relevant part: â€œRelating Only to All
  Landlord/Tenant Issues.â€ Paragraphs 7 and 10 of the Settlement Agreement state
  that the parties agree to dismiss with prejudice all litigation involving the
  premises, store, any business on the premises, and/or the relationship between
  the parties, including all claims between Pee Dee Stores and Doyle, and all landlord/tenant
  issues between all parties.Â  These provisions clearly resolved the claims
  between Doyle and Huggins and Pee Dee Stores in the ejectment action, as well
  as all of the claims against Doyle and counterclaims by Doyle in the breach of
  contract case.Â  This was the basis for Doyle and Hugginsâ€™ motion to amend their
  pleadings.Â  
However, the language of the Settlement Agreement does
  not provide a definition of â€œlandlord/tenant claims.â€ This phrase is not a
  legal term of art; rather, it is shorthand for the partiesâ€™ conceptualization
  of the claims that should be labeled as â€œlandlord-tenant.â€Â  Therefore, the Settlement
  Agreement is ambiguous as to the scope and application of â€œlandlord/tenant
  claims.â€ Â It is unclear whether the parties intended that the Settlement Agreement
  resolve Hugginsâ€™ civil conspiracy and unfair trade practices claims against Pee
  Dee Stores and Helena because it is uncertain whether â€œlandlord/tenant claimsâ€
  includes civil conspiracy and unfair trade practices claims.Â  Reasonable minds
  can certainly differ as to the meaning of â€œlandlord/tenant claims.â€Â  
The language of the Settlement Agreement does not
  support the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that all of Hugginsâ€™ claims were
  extinguished.Â  That construction is implausible, particularly because it would nullify
  Paragraph 8 of the Settlement Agreement, which clearly sought to exclude some
  of Hugginsâ€™ claims from the ambit of the Settlement Agreement.Â  The language of
  Paragraph 8 unequivocally states that the parties agreed that Huggins never
  intended to relinquish all of his claims against Pee Dee Stores and Helena and,
  in fact, clearly excludes Hugginsâ€™ non-landlord/tenant claims from
  resolution by the Settlement Agreement.Â  It is highly unlikely that the
  language of Paragraph 8 was included in the Agreement but yet meant to have no
  effect.Â  The parties must have intended that non-landlord/tenant claims survive
  the Settlement Agreement.Â  Had it been the partiesâ€™ intention to extinguish all
  claims by Huggins, the Settlement Agreement could have simply done so, instead
  of expressly carving out specific exceptions in Paragraphs 7, 8, and 10 to
  exclude Hugginsâ€™ non-landlord/tenant claims.Â  The language of the
  Settlement Agreement does not indicate that it was the partiesâ€™ intention to
  resolve all claims. 
Further, Pee Dee Storesâ€™ various statements concerning
  its own interpretation of the Settlement Agreement are inconsistent and improbable,
  again demonstrating that there was a genuine issue of material fact that
  rendered summary judgment improper.Â  Pee Dee Stores contends that the â€œand/or []
  relationship between the partiesâ€ language of Paragraph 7 was intended to be broadly
  interpreted to waive all claims relating to the relationship between the
  parties, including the civil conspiracy and unfair trade practices claims.Â  Yet,
  elsewhere in its brief Pee Dee Stores states:

	[Huggins and Doyle] also allege the Settlement
  Agreement is ambiguous because Huggins only agreed to dismiss with prejudice
  the landlord/tenant claims and issues, and thus reserved the right to sue [Pee
  Dee Stores] for other things. That is partially correct â€” the Settlement
  Agreement certainly does not apply, for example, to any open accounts [Pee Dee
  Stores] may have with Appellant Huggins, etc. However, Huggins clearly and
  unambiguously resolved with prejudice all landlord/tenant claims and issues,
  defined in the Settlement Agreement as â€œany litigation involving the premises,
  the store, any business on the premises, and/or the relationship between the
  Parties. Â 

Contrary to its assertion above, Pee Dee Storesâ€™ broad interpretation
  of the Settlement Agreement would also preclude Huggins from litigating any
  open accounts with Pee Dee Stores, as these open accounts would certainly
  pertain to the relationship between the parties.Â  Moreover, Pee Dee Stores
  moved to amend its pleadings to reflect the Settlement Agreement, which is
  inconsistent with its contention that the Settlement Agreement dismissed all
  claims. 
In view of the fact that an ambiguity exists in the
  Settlement Agreement regarding the scope and definition of â€œlandlord/tenant
  claims,â€ this Court would have to strain to determine the partiesâ€™ intention,
  and it is not at liberty to do so.Â  See Blakely 266 S.C. at 73,
  221 S.E.2d at 769.Â  Thus, the partiesâ€™ intention is a question of fact to be
  ascertained by the trier of fact.Â  To ascertain the partiesâ€™ intent, the trier
  of fact must look at the language of the Settlement Agreement, the
  circumstances known to the parties at the time, and all other pertinent
  extrinsic evidence. 
The trial court committed reversible error in granting
  Pee Dee Storesâ€™ summary judgment motion and motion to compel settlement. Â The
  definition of â€œlandlord/tenant claimsâ€ is susceptible to more than one
  interpretation, and therefore, the contract is ambiguous.Â  Because of the
  ambiguous nature of the contract, a genuine issue of material fact exists as to
  whether it was the intent of the parties to extinguish Hugginsâ€™ claims for
  civil conspiracy and unfair trade practices.[4] Â 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s order is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HUFF, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur. Â 


[1] Carolyn Doyle succeeded to Paul E. Doyleâ€™s rights
  under the lease after his death.
[2] Huggins was not a party to the lease agreement.
[3] This action was subsequently transferred to trial
  court.Â  
[4] We decline to address Pee Dee Storesâ€™ purported
  sustaining grounds on appeal as our determination that the language of the
  Settlement Agreement is ambiguous is dispositive.Â  See Futch v.
    McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591,
  598 (1999) (the appellate court need not address remaining issues when the disposition
  of other issues is dispositive).

title: Southeastern Housing Foundation v. Smith
description: In this appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court's grant of a 60(b) motion for relief from judgment to a non-profit housing foundation and affirmed the grant of summary judgment for legal malpractice against its attorney.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
02-CP-06-314

	
		
			
				Southeastern Housing Foundation f/k/a Southeastern South
      Carolina Housing, Inc., Appellant-Respondent,
				v.
				John Michael
      Smith, Stephen Mark Nettles, Sally Smith and Dawn N. Nettles, Defendants, of whom John
          Michael Smith and Sally Smith are Respondents-Appellants.
				02-CP-06-315
				Southeastern Housing Foundation
        f/k/a Southeastern South Carolina
        Housing, Inc., Appellant-Respondent,
				 
				v.
				Calhoun
      Insurance Agency, Inc. a/k/a Calhoun Insurance Company, Inc. and John Michael
      Smith, Respondents-Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Barnwell County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4468
Heard October 7, 2008 â€“ Filed December 12,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William Howell
  Morrison, Phyllis W. Ewing, of Charleston, for Appellant-Respondent.
				Curtis W.
  Dowling, R. Jeffords Barham, J. Todd Kincannon, of Columbia, for Respondents-Appellants.
			
		
	

GEATHERS,
  J.: This consolidated appeal arises
  from two suits filed by the nonprofit corporation, Southeastern Housing
  Foundation (the Foundation).Â  In the first action, the Foundation sued its former
  attorney, John Michael â€œPatâ€ Smith (Smith), Smithâ€™s wife, its former developer,
  Stephen Nettles (Nettles), and Nettlesâ€™ wife for civil conspiracy, negligence,
  breach of fiduciary duty, legal malpractice, and misappropriation of assets in
  connection with several affordable housing financing transactions.Â  In the
  second action, the Foundation sued Smith and the Calhoun Insurance Agency, of
  which Smith is the registered agent and a shareholder, for the recovery of real
  estate and improvements on property leased to the Foundation.Â  
The
  Foundation appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of the Smiths
  and the Calhoun Insurance Agency.Â  The Foundation argues that the trial court
  erred in finding the Foundationâ€™s newly appointed board of directors (New
  Board) was not properly installed such that the New Board was unauthorized to
  file suit on behalf of the Foundation.[1]Â  Smith also appeals on
  several grounds claiming the trial court improperly vacated its order of
  summary judgment when it granted the Foundationâ€™s motion for relief from judgment
  under Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  Smith mainly contends the Foundation manufactured a post
  hoc resolution permitting court-appointed custodians to file suit on behalf of
  the Foundation only after summary judgment was granted, which precluded the
  resolution from being deemed â€œnewly discovered evidenceâ€ as required to grant
  relief under Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  We agree that the trial court properly
  granted the Foundationâ€™s 60(b) motion, and as such, we decline to address the
  Foundationâ€™s arguments for reversing the grant of summary judgment, save the
  Foundationâ€™s argument regarding the legal malpractice claim.[2] Â 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORYÂ Â Â Â Â Â  
A
  discussion of the underlying facts and relationships between the parties is
  necessary for an understanding of this appealâ€™s extensive and complex history.Â  
The
  Foundation was created in 1976 as a nonprofit corporation pursuant to state and
  federal law.[3]Â  As stated in its
  articles of incorporation, its purpose is â€œto provide, on a nonprofit basis,
  housing for lower income families, where no adequate housing exists . . . .â€Â 
  Consistent with this purpose, the Foundation is â€œauthorized to engage in or
  assist in the development or operation of low-income housing . . . .â€ 24 C.F.R.
  Â§ 811.102 (2008). 
The
  Foundationâ€™s housing operations are largely intertwined with the South Carolina
  Regional Housing Authority No. 3 (Housing Authority).Â  The Housing Authority is
  a creature of state law with the â€œpower to acquire property, to remove
  unsanitary or substandard conditions, to construct and operate housing
  accommodations and to borrow, expend, lend and repay moneys for [these]
  purposes . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 31-3-30, 31-3-910 (Supp. 2007).Â  As a
  quasi-governmental/state entity, the Housing Authority essentially serves as a
  paid management company for the Foundationâ€™s affordable housing properties.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 31-3-20(10), 31-3-450, 31-3-530 (Supp. 2007).Â  
Federal
  regulations governing subsidized housing allow an applicant, such as the
  Foundation, to participate in programs under Section 11(b) of the United States
  Housing Act of 1937.[4]Â  The United States
  Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) allows an applicant to
  qualify for participation in programs under Section 11(b) if the applicant
  identifies its â€œparent entityâ€ public housing authority and proves that it is a
  nonprofit entity that serves as an authorized agency or instrumentality of the
  parent entity.Â  See 24 C.F.R. Â§ 811.105 (2008).Â  
As
  stated in its bylaws, all of the Foundationâ€™s corporate powers were to be
  exercised by its board of directors, â€œexcept as otherwise provided by [HUD] and
  the Federal Housing Administration.â€Â  Further, the Foundation was empowered to
  enter into â€œa Regulatory Agreement with the Secretary of [HUD] . . . to enable
  the [Foundation] to secure the benefits of financing with the assistance of
  mortgage insurance under the provisions of the National Housing Act.â€Â  To
  comply with HUDâ€™s federal regulations, the Foundation amended its bylaws in
  1978 to include a provision that one of its purposes was to â€œotherwise assist
  and be utilized as a â€˜public housing agencyâ€™ approved by [HUD] . . . [and] by
  the South Carolina Regional Housing Authority No. 3.â€Â  The Foundation also
  stated in this amendment that upon dissolution, its property would vest in the
  Housing Authority.Â  
After
  these amendments to its bylaws, the Foundation did not actively operate for
  almost twenty years.Â  In the mid-1990s, Smith, who served as the part-time
  Executive Director of the Housing Authority, and Nettles, who served as the
  Director of Management of the Housing Authority, learned of a program
  administered by HUD.[5]Â  Under the program, the
  Secretary of HUD is empowered to enter into contracts with state and local
  public housing agencies and fund these agencies through annual contribution
  contracts.Â  See 42 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1437f(b) (2008).Â  In turn, the program encourages
  public housing authorities to establish nonprofits.Â  Once established, a
  nonprofit entity can own affordable housing, obtain grants for rehabilitation
  of properties, and enter into management agreements with housing authorities.Â 
  The concept behind the program was that the Foundation would own the
  properties, but the Housing Authority would manage the properties for a fee. 
Pursuant
  to this program, Nettles and Smith revitalized the Foundation and entered into
  an agreement with the Housing Authority on July 1, 1996 regarding both entitiesâ€™
  roles in the program.[6]Â  Under this agreement,
  the Foundation agreed to accept the Housing Authority as its â€œParent Agencyâ€ in
  order to assist the Foundation with management and financial support until the
  Foundation became self-sufficient.Â  Consistent with the Foundationâ€™s agreement
  to be managed by the Housing Authority, the General Certificate executed at the
  first meeting of the revitalized Foundation set forth the board of directors.Â 
  It stated that three of the four directors were serving â€œAt [the] Will of [the
  Housing] Authorityâ€ and that each was â€œduly qualified to act in the official
  [designated] capacity.â€Â  
After
  entering into this agreement with the Housing Authority, the Foundation applied
  for tax-exempt status under 26 U.S.C.A. Â§ 501(c)(3).Â  In its application to the
  Internal Revenue Service (IRS), the Foundation stated it would buy, rent, and
  sell houses to low-income families â€œthrough and [with the] support [of the]
  South Carolina Regional Housing Authority No. 3.â€Â  The Foundation also submitted
  an opinion letter written by attorney Lee Bowers, which stated that the
  Foundation was â€œan agency or instrumentality of the S.C. Regional Housing
  Authority, No. 3, i.e., parent entity.â€Â  The Foundation further represented
  that it would be controlled by and financially accountable to the Housing
  Authority.Â  Based on these statements and other submissions, the IRS granted
  the Foundationâ€™s application. 
The
  Foundation then began to purchase and finance affordable housing properties,
  notably the â€œMarlboro Street Property,â€ which is the subject of the
  Foundationâ€™s second action, in Barnwell, South Carolina.Â  In almost all of
  these transactions, Smith, as the Foundationâ€™s attorney, and Nettles, as the
  Foundationâ€™s developer, received fees for either legal or development work.Â  
In
  February 2002, Smith and Nettles had a falling out, which led to mutual
  accusations of improper conduct and ended with Nettles filing a grievance
  against Smith with the Housing Authority.Â  Based on these allegations,
  the Housing Authorityâ€™s board of commissioners (Board of Commissioners)
  requested that HUD conduct an audit of the Foundation and directed the
  Foundation to â€œ[i]mmediately dismissâ€ its current board of directors. Â In
  March 2002, the Housing Authority appointed three of its own commissioners as
  new board members for the Foundation and assumed control of the Foundationâ€™s
  affairs.Â  
On
  May 30, 2002, the Housing Authorityâ€™s legal counsel sent letters to the
  remaining four former board members (Former Board) requesting their formal
  resignations and execution of a unanimous consent resolution granting authority
  to the Housing Authority to elect a new board.Â  In the letter, counsel stated
  that if the Former Board did not consent, counsel would be required to advise the
  Board of Commissioners of its legal options.Â  Two of the four members resigned,
  and when the remaining two members refused, the Housing Authority filed a
  derivative action against them.Â  In response, the remaining two board members
  resigned, and the suit was dismissed with prejudice.[7]Â 
  The Housing Authority then filled the remaining vacancies on the Foundationâ€™s
  board in June 2002.Â Â  
During
  the time that the Housing Authority was attempting to obtain the Former Boardâ€™s
  resignation, the Inspector General of HUD was performing an audit of the
  Foundation.[8]Â  The report concluded
  that Smith and Nettles â€œtook advantage of their positions . . . to financially
  benefit themselves, their families, and friends at the expense of [the Housing
  Authority and the Foundation].â€[9]Â  The audit stated that
  any net earnings beyond those needed for â€œthe retirement of project debt or to
  carry out low-income housing projects were not to inure to the benefit of any
  person or entity other than the parent entity, the Authority.â€Â  As such, HUD
  concluded that Smith and Nettlesâ€™ collection of over $958,738 in
  development and other fees on Foundation property purchases was inappropriate.Â 
  The audit also opined that the Housing Authorityâ€™s agreement with the
  Foundation to provide financial and administrative support was illegal because
  HUD funds can only be used for projects that have been explicitly approved by
  HUD. 
Based
  on this audit, the Housing Authority filed suit against Smith regarding alleged
  incentive compensation he received while Executive Director of the Housing
  Authority.Â  In addition, the Foundation filed two suits in December 2002, which
  were later consolidated and are now before this Court.Â  The first suit was
  against the Smiths and the Nettles to recover the above-mentioned fees and
  other damages,[10] and the second action
  was against Smith and the Calhoun Insurance Agency for alleged misdeeds over
  the purchase and subsequent lease of the Marlboro Street Property.[11]Â Â  
In
  April 2005, the Smiths and the Nettles filed a summary judgment motion pursuant
  to Rule 56, SCRCP, as to all causes of action and alleged the New Board was
  without authority to file suit on behalf of the Foundation.Â  After the trial
  court held a hearing on the motion, but before it issued its order, two members
  of the New Board filed an action for judicial dissolution of the Foundation and
  petitioned the trial court to appoint a custodian for the Foundation pending
  the outcome of the litigation.Â  On June 22, 2005, the trial court signed an
  order appointing three custodians for the Foundation.[12]Â 
  The trial court authorized the custodians to exercise all powers of the
  corporation through or in place of the New Board and to sue and defend on
  behalf of the Foundation.Â  It also expressly charged the custodians with ensuring
  that the Foundationâ€™s financial obligations were met, with ratifying any
  actions taken by the New Board if in the best interests of the Foundation, and
  with informing the trial court about the custodiansâ€™ positions on any pending
  lawsuits involving the Foundation.Â  
On
  June 23, 2005, the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the Smiths
  and the Nettles on the grounds that the New Board was created illegally and
  thus lacked the power to file suit on behalf of the Foundation.Â  The trial court
  also held that the Foundationâ€™s claims against Smith for legal malpractice were
  fatally flawed due to its failure to present an expert witness to establish
  Smithâ€™s required duty of care.Â  Following entry of summary judgment, the
  Foundation timely filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.
On
  August 1, 2005, two days prior to the trial courtâ€™s hearing on the 59(e)
  motion, the custodians filed a resolution with the trial court, ratifying the
  filing of the lawsuits, which the trial court had voided in its grant of
  summary judgment.Â  The trial court formally denied the Foundationâ€™s 59(e)
  motion on December 9, 2005, reasoning that because the custodiansâ€™ resolution
  was not before the trial court when it initially ruled on the summary judgment
  motion, it would be improper to consider the custodiansâ€™ resolution in ruling
  on the 59(e) motion. 
The
  Foundation then properly perfected an appeal to this Court on December 22,
  2005.Â  Almost six months later on June 20, 2006, the Foundation moved for
  relief from judgment under Rules 60(b)(2) and 60(b)(5), SCRCP, in tandem with a
  motion to this Court for leave to file the 60(b) motion with the trial court.Â 
  On August 25, 2006, this Court granted the Foundationâ€™s motion for leave, thus
  conferring jurisdiction on the trial court to address the 60(b) motion. 
On
  November 28, 2006, the trial court granted the Foundationâ€™s 60(b)(2), SCRCP,
  motion finding the custodiansâ€™ resolution was â€œnewly discovered evidence which
  by due diligence could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial
  . . . .â€Â  In its order, the trial court found that the New Boardâ€™s filing of
  the lawsuit on behalf of the Foundation was a voidable act.Â  However, while the
  New Board may have been illegally formed, because the Foundation had the
  authority to bring suit in its name as a distinct jural entity, the subsequent
  ratification by legally-appointed custodians cured that voidable act.Â  As a
  result, the custodiansâ€™ resolution ratifying the New Boardâ€™s filing of the
  lawsuits was evidence of the Foundationâ€™s intent at the time of the initial
  filing.Â  Thus, the trial court relieved the Foundation from its earlier summary
  judgment ruling on all causes of action except its grant of summary judgment in
  favor of Smith for legal malpractice.Â  The Smiths and the Calhoun
  Insurance Agency timely filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, which the trial
  court denied on March 26, 2007.[13]Â  This appeal follows.
ISSUES ON APPEAL
Smith appeals the
  trial courtâ€™s grant of the Foundationâ€™s
  motion for relief from judgment under Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP, on several grounds.[14]Â 
  First, Smith argues the custodiansâ€™ resolution ratifying the Foundationâ€™s
  lawsuit was not â€œnewly discovered evidenceâ€ as is required for relief under
  Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  Second, Smith argues the 60(b)(2) motion was filed
  outside the one-year time limit and was not filed within a â€œreasonable timeâ€
  after the resolution was discovered.Â  Smith additionally contends that the
  custodiansâ€™ ratification of the filing of the lawsuits was invalid because the
  custodians were never properly appointed.Â  Smith next argues that S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 33-31-1008 prohibits a corporation from affecting ongoing litigation
  through amendments to the articles, and because the custodiansâ€™ resolution was
  actually an articles amendment, the trial court erred in relying on it to grant

Whether

  the trial court. Â Coleman v. Dunlap, 306 S.C. 491, 494, 413 S.E.2d 15,

  10, 18, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 (2004).Â  An abuse of discretion arises when the
  order was controlled by an error of law or when the order is based on factual

CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  HUFF, J., concur. Â 


[1] For ease of reference, the Court will refer to
  â€œSmithâ€ throughout the opinion for any claims pertaining to Smith, Smithâ€™s
  wife, and the Calhoun Insurance Agency. 
[2] Because the Foundation will have received its
  requested relief, its remaining issues on appeal will be moot.Â  See Seabrook
    v. Knox, 369 S.C. 191, 197, 631 S.E.2d 907, 910 (2006) (recognizing that
  this Court will not decide questions on which a judgment rendered will have no
  practical legal effect). 
[3] The Foundation was originally named â€œSoutheastern
  South Carolina Housing, Inc.â€Â  Its name was officially changed on June 5, 1997
  to â€œSoutheastern Housing Foundationâ€ to reflect its status as a public benefit
  corporation.Â  
[4] As amended and consolidated with other housing
  statutes to form the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C.A.
  Â§Â§ 1437 to 1437z-8.
[5] Smith, as an original incorporator of the Foundation,
  served as a member of the Foundationâ€™s board of directors from its inception in
  1976 until he resigned in July 1997.Â  
[6] When the Foundation entered into this agreement with
  the Housing Authority, Nettles was both the Executive Director of the
  Foundation and Director of Management of the Housing Authority and Smith was
  the part-time Executive Director of the Housing Authority. Â This coterminous
  representation is permissible pursuant to 24 C.F.R. Â§ 811.105(e) (2008) (â€œMembers,
  officers, or employees of the parent entity [public housing authority] may be
  directors or officers of the applicant unless this is contrary to state law.â€).
[7] Smith alleges the New Board failed to follow
  statutory guidelines in filing its unanimous consent resolution to remove the
  Former Board and in obtaining the written resignations of the Former Board.Â 
  Because we find the court-appointed custodians, acting as the Foundation, had
  the authority to file the lawsuits, we decline to address these arguments as
  the boardâ€™s former or present constitution has no bearing on the ability of the
  Foundation to file suit.Â Â Â Â  
[8] Because the Foundation was a recipient of annual
  contribution contracts for its low-income housing projects, 42 U.S.C.A. Â§
  1437c(h)(1) required the Foundation to provide HUD with the right to audit.
[9] At the time of the audit in 1999, the respective board
  members included: (1) Nettlesâ€™ wife, Dawn Nettles; (2) Smithâ€™s wife, Sally
  Smith; (3) Smithâ€™s employee, Melissa Still; (4) Dawn Nettlesâ€™ mother, Kathleen
  Norton; (5) Sally Smithâ€™s brother-in-law, Bobby Kinard; (6) Sally Smithâ€™s niece
  and Bobby Kinardâ€™s daughter, Julie Welch; and (7) Dawn Nettlesâ€™ sister, Valerie
  Kraun. 
[10] The Foundation also sued Smithâ€™s wife, Sally Smith,
  and Nettlesâ€™ wife, Dawn Nettles, due to their employment with the Foundation at
  the time of the alleged wrongdoings.Â  The Foundation has since settled its case
  against the Nettles.Â  
[11] The Foundation filed suit against Smith and the
  Calhoun Insurance Agency for breach of fiduciary duty, tortious interference
  with contract, and constructive trust.Â  These claims stemmed from the purchase
  and subsequent leasing of the Marlboro Street Property, which was used by the
  Foundation and the Housing Authority for office space.Â  The Foundation
  alleged that Smith, while legal counsel for the Foundation, improperly assigned
  the sales contract to himself, charged property taxes to the Foundation, which
  otherwise would not have accrued due to its 501(c)(3) status, and improperly
  assessed improvements and rental fees against the Foundation. See Southeastern
    Housing Foundation f/k/a Southeastern South Carolina Housing, Inc. v. Calhoun
    Insurance Agency, Inc., and John Michael Smith, C/A No. 02-CP-06-315. 
[12] The trial court entered its initial order appointing
  the custodians on June 6, 2005.Â  After receiving comments from the parties, the
  trial court amended its initial order on June 22, 2005 and filed the order on
  June 24, 2005. 
[13] The Foundation contends that Smithâ€™s appeal is
  untimely because he failed to appeal the 60(b) motion within thirty days of its
  issuance.Â  The Foundation argues that a Rule 59(e) motion is only appropriate
  to alter or amend a â€œjudgment,â€ and because the grant of the 60(b) motion
  neither dismisses the action nor finally determines the rights of any party, it
  is not a judgment within the meaning of the Rules.Â  Thus, the 60(b) motion was untimely
  because the time to appeal was not stayed upon the filing of the 59(e) motion.Â 
  We disagree.Â  Under this analysis, if the trial court fails to address issues
  raised by a party at the 60(b) stage, the party would be forced to file a
  direct appeal without the benefit of first submitting a 59(e) motion to the
  trial court. Further, while a Rule 59(e) motion is a vehicle to alter or amend
  a judgment, it is also a means to reconsider previously raised issues and
  arguments.Â  See Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 21,
  602 S.E.2d 772, 778 (2004).Â  Without first submitting a 59(e) motion to the
  trial court, this Court could then dispose of the partyâ€™s arguments on error
  preservation principles.Â  See Iâ€™on, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant,
  338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (â€œThe losing party must first try
  to convince the lower court it is [sic] has ruled wrongly and then, if that
  effort fails, convince the appellate court that the lower court erred. This
  principle underlies the long-established preservation requirement that the
  losing party generally must both present his issues and arguments to the lower
  court and obtain a ruling before an appellate court will review those issues
  and arguments.â€). Â Because Rules 59 and 60(b) must be read together, Smithâ€™s
  59(e) motion in response to the 60(b) ruling was proper.Â  See Gray v.
    Bryant, 298 S.C. 285, 287, 379 S.E.2d 894, 895 (1989) (â€œIt is our view that
  Rules 59 and 60(b) must be read together.â€).Â  
[14] Even if the order granting the 60(b) motion is
  not immediately appealable, this Court may review an interlocutory order when
  the order is coupled with an appealable issue.Â  See Edge v. State
    Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 511, 517, 623 S.E.2d 387, 390 (2005); Briggs
      v. Richardson, 273 S.C. 376, 379 n.1, 256 S.E.2d 544, 546 n.1 (1979); Pitts
        v. Jackson Natâ€™l Life Ins. Co., 352 S.C. 319, 338, 574 S.E.2d 502, 511-12
  (Ct. App. 2002); Cox v. Woodmen of World Ins. Co., 347 S.C. 460, 469,
  556 S.E.2d 397, 402 (Ct. App. 2001). But cf.Â  Pocisk v. Sea Coast
    Constr., Op. No. 4460 (S.C. Ct. App. filed November 20, 2008) (Shearouse
  Adv. Sh. No. 44 at 49) (finding partiesâ€™ appeal from trial courtâ€™s order
  granting 60(b) reliefÂ  was not immediately appealable where the 60(b) order was
  the only issue before this Court and the orderâ€™s appealability was specifically
  raised on appeal).Â  Because the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on the
  Foundationâ€™s legal malpractice claim is a final determination that is properly
  before this Court, we believe judicial economy argues for the resolution of
  Smithâ€™s arguments on the 60(b) motion at this time.Â  See Edge,
  366 S.C. at 517, 623 S.E.2d at 390 (finding resolution of partial denial of
  motion to dismiss was proper when it was coupled with appeal from partial grant
  of motion to dismiss because resolution of both was â€œin an effort to avoid
  another appeal in the future and potentially narrow the issues for trial (i.e.
  judicial economy)â€).
[15] A motion for a new trial pursuant to Rule 59(b) â€œshall
  be made not later than 10 days after the receipt of written notice of the entry
  of judgment or of the filing of an order disposing of the action, if no
  judgment has been entered.â€Â  Rule 59, SCRCP.Â  
[16] The Foundation asserts in its brief that Smith cannot
  attack the validity of the custodians as Smith never appealed from the trial
  courtâ€™s appointment order, and thus, Smithâ€™s attack on the validity of the
  custodial appointment is an improper collateral attack.Â  Because the
  appointment of a custodian, as contrasted with the appointment of a receiver,
  is an interlocutory order and thus not immediately appealable based on this
  Courtâ€™s decision in Shapemasters Golf Course Buiders, Inc., v. Shapemasters,
    Inc., 360 S.C. 473, 602 S.E.2d 83 (Ct. App. 2004), we will address Smithâ€™s
  argument.Â  We express no opinion on whether Smithâ€™s failure to appear at the
  hearing on the custodiansâ€™ appointment renders his attack on the appointment
  improper.Â  
[17] Harley and Haley also served coextensively on the
  Housing Authorityâ€™s Board of Commissioners when they petitioned for judicial
  dissolution and custodial appointment. Â See 24 C.F.R. Â§ 811.105(e)
  (2008) (â€œMembers, officers, or employees of the parent entity PHA may be
  directors of officers of the applicant unless this is contrary to state law.â€).
[18] We recognize the dismissal of the legal malpractice
  claim would extinguish the breach of fiduciary duty cause of action against
  Smith in the first action.Â  However, whether Smith can still be found to have
  breached a duty to the Foundation as the Executive Director of the Housing
  Authority, as the registered agent and shareholder of the Calhoun Insurance Agency,
  or as a board member of the Foundation in the second action is still a jury
  question regardless of his role as the Foundationâ€™s attorney.

title: Hartfield v. McDonald
description: Jon Hartfield and Haskell L. Hartfield, individually and as Conservator to John Hartfield, (collectively referred to as Hartfield) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict in favor of Respondents Robert Cockrell, individually and d/b/a Williams Package and South Pointe Pubâ€™s (collectively referred to as the Pub). THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jon E.
      Hartfield, by and through his Conservator, Haskell L. Hartfield, and Haskell
      L. Hartfield, individually, Appellants,
				v.
				Glenn McDonald,
      d/b/a The Carolina Lounge, and The Getaway Lounge & Grill, Inc., and
      Shou-Mei Morris, Individually and as President of the Getaway Lounge &
      and Grill, Inc., Robert C. Cockrell, individually and d/b/a Williams Package
      and South Pointe Pub, Defendants,
				Of whom, The
      Getaway Lounge & Grill, Inc., and Shou-Mei Morris, individually and as
      President of The Getaway Lounge & Grill, Inc.,Â  andÂ  Robert C. Cockrell,
      individually and d/b/a Williams Package and South Pointe Pub are, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenwood County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â Â  4469
Heard October 21, 2008 â€“ Filed December
  17, 2008 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Jon E. Newlon, of Greenwood, for Appellants.
				C. Rauch Wise and Marvin R. Watson, both of Greenwood, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.: Â Jon Hartfield and
  Haskell L. Hartfield, individually and as Conservator to Jon Hartfield,
  (collectively referred to as Hartfield) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a
  directed verdict in favor of Respondents
  Robert Cockrell, individually and d/b/a Williams Package and South Pointe Pub
  (collectively referred to as the Pub).Â  Hartfield contends the circuit court
  erred in directing a verdict in favor of the Pub because there was sufficient
  evidence presented to the court to survive the Pubâ€™s motion for a directed
  verdict.Â  Hartfield also contends the circuit court erroneously required direct
  evidence of service of alcohol and level of intoxication.Â  We affirm. 

FACTS
Hoyt Helton was a frequent drinker who many considered
  an alcoholic.Â  Heltonâ€™s wife testified that over the course of their eleven-year
  marriage, Helton drank Bud Light or Budweiser beer every day, and had gotten in
  trouble for drinking and driving â€œa number of times.â€Â  She also
  described Heltonâ€™s drinking style as a â€œsipper,â€ and said that he weighed
  between one-hundred thirty, and one-hundred fifty pounds.Â  On July 11, 2003,
  after an evening out at several drinking establishments, Helton crossed the
  centerline of a highway in a car he was driving.Â  Heltonâ€™s vehicle struck a car
  driven by Laura Riddle, and in which Jon Hartfield was a passenger.Â  Helton
  died at the scene.Â  Testing conducted after the accident revealed Heltonâ€™s
  blood alcohol content (BAC) was .212.Â  Riddle and Hartfield were seriously
  injured, and Hartfield was in a coma for several months after the accident.Â  As
  a result of his injuries, Hartfield requires assisted living arrangements for
  the remainder of his life.Â  
On the day of the
  accident, Helton left his house sometime between 1:15 and 5:45 p.m., according
  to his wife.Â  Cockrell, one of two owners and managers of the Pub, was tending
  bar at the Pub on that particular day and testified Helton arrived between 4
  and 4:15 p.m.Â  Helton exited the Pub at approximately 5:30 p.m.Â  Cockrell did
  not see Helton again until he was closing for the night at 7 p.m., when he saw
  Helton sitting on a bench in front of the Pub.Â  In addition, Cockrell testified
  he neither served Helton a beer, nor saw him drinking while he was inside the
  establishment, and testified Helton was not in possession of a beer on the
  bench when Cockrell left.Â  
Brad Harrison, a
  drinking buddy of Heltonâ€™s, testified he arrived at the Pub that day around 6 p.m.
  and Helton was sitting outside on a bench.Â  Harrison recalled Helton was not
  drinking, and that from the time Harrison arrived, until 7:10 p.m. when he
  left, Helton did not drink a beverage of any kind.Â  Thereafter, Helton made his
  way to the The Getaway Lounge
  & Grill, Inc. (The Getaway), where
  the bartender that evening, Diane Bice, testified Helton arrived between 7:15
  and 7:30 p.m.Â  According to her testimony, Helton left The Getaway around 8 p.m.,
  and in the time he was there, Bice neither served nor observed Helton
  drinking.Â  Harrison, however, testified he arrived at The Getaway at 8 p.m.,
  and while he was there, Helton was sitting at the bar and consumed two to three
  beers.Â  Both Harrison and Bice testified Helton did not appear intoxicated
  while at The Getaway.Â  
Finally, Helton
  made his way to The Carolina
  Lounge (Carolina), where bartender Billy
  McDonald testified Helton arrived at approximately 10 p.m. and left shortly
  thereafter around 10:15 p.m.Â  McDonald recalled Helton sat at the bar and was
  not served a beer; however, Highway Patrolman Tony Keller testified he spoke
  with McDonald on the phone shortly after the accident, and McDonald admitted
  Helton had been served and had consumed one beer at Carolina.Â  McDonald also
  told Keller that Helton was sober when he left Carolina at 10:15 p.m.Â  The
  accident occurred at approximately 10:51 p.m.Â  
Hartfield filed
  suit against Cockrell, individually, and the Pub; Shou-Mei Morris, individually, and The Getaway Lounge & Grill, Inc.;
  and Glenn McDonald, d/b/a The
  Carolina Lounge.Â  Hartfield contended
  each of the defendants was negligent, grossly negligent, careless, reckless,
  willful and wanton, under a rubric of dram shop liability, and that the
  defendantsâ€™ actions were the direct and proximate cause of the injuries and
  damages he received. Â At the close of Hartfieldâ€™s case, the circuit court
  granted Cockrellâ€™s and the Pubâ€™s motions for directed verdict.Â  A jury verdict
  was obtained against Morris and The Getaway, and the circuit court declared a
  mistrial as to McDonald and Carolina.Â  Only the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a
  directed verdict in favor of the Pub is before this court on appeal.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hartfield contends the circuit court erred in
  directing a verdict in favor of the Pub because there was sufficient evidence
  presented to the court from which a reasonable juror could find Helton appeared
  visibly intoxicated and was served alcohol at the Pub.Â  Hartfield also contends
  the circuit court erred by requiring direct evidence of service of alcohol and
  level of intoxication, rather than finding the circumstantial evidence provided
  at trial created a sufficient jury question.Â  We disagree.
Section 61-4-580 of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) prohibits the sale of beer or wine to an
  intoxicated person.Â  That section specifically provides:

	Prohibited
  acts.
	No
  holder of a permit authorizing the sale of beer or wine or a servant, agent, or
  employee of the permittee may knowingly commit any of the following acts upon
  the licensed premises covered by the holderâ€™s permit:
	. . .
	(2)
  sell beer or wine to an intoxicated person[.]

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-580(2).Â 
  This Court has previously held that Â§ 61-4-580â€™s predecessor supplied a private
  cause of action for civil liability to a third party who is injured as a result
  of a violation of the statute.Â  Daley v. Ward, 303 S.C. 81, 83-84, 399
  S.E.2d 13, 14 (Ct. App. 1990) (interpreting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-9-410 (1976)).
As indicated above,
  testimony from all parties who witnessed Helton on the night of the accident
  was that he was neither visibly intoxicated, nor actually served alcohol while
  at the Pub. Â As a result, Hartfield called a series of experts to establish
  Heltonâ€™s intoxication at the time he died, and by virtue of his height, weight,
  drinking style, and the nightâ€™s general timeline, introduced circumstantial
  evidence to prove Helton would have been visibly intoxicated during the time he
  was at the Pub.Â  Dr. William Brewer was qualified before the court as an expert
  in toxicology.Â  Brewer testified as to the general effects of alcohol on people
  based on their physical characteristics, as well as the physical manifestations
  an intoxicated person would exhibit given the level of his or her
  intoxication.Â  Brewer then explained to the jury how retrograde extrapolation[1] could be used to determine the level of intoxication of a person at any point
  during the night.Â  
The circuit court
  ultimately prevented parts of Brewerâ€™s retrograde extrapolation analysis from
  introduction before the jury.Â  Hartfield contends the proffered circumstantial
  evidence may be used to establish service of alcohol and the level of a personâ€™s
  intoxication at the time of service.Â  In support of this contention, Hartfield
  points to several other courts and jurisdictions that have allowed the
  introduction of circumstantial evidence in dram shop cases. See Alaniz
    v. Rebello Food & Beverage, L.L.C., 165 S.W.3d 7 (Tex. App. 2005); Romano
      v. Stanley, 684 N.E.2d 19 (N.Y. 1997); People v. Ladd, 675 N.E.2d
  1211 (N.Y. 1996).Â  In addition, Hartfield cites Daley v. Ward, which
  states a jury could determine from circumstantial evidence whether a person was
  visibly intoxicated such that a prudent man would have known of his condition.Â  Daley, 303 S.C. at 87, 399 S.E.2d at 16.Â  However, in each of the cases
  cited by Hartfield, the sale or consumption of alcohol at the establishments in
  question was either admitted to, or proven by other evidence.Â  We find
  Hartfieldâ€™s lack of evidence as to the Pubâ€™s sale of alcohol fatal to his argument.
Moreover, each of
  the cases cited by Hartfield is factually distinguishable from the case at
  hand.Â  In Daley, this court held that the circuit court erred in its
  response to a jury question, because it removed from the province of the jury the
  issue of whether circumstantial evidence could establish visible intoxication.Â  Daley, 303 S.C. at 87, 399 S.E.2d at 16.Â  However, the intoxicated
  patron admitted that he drank nine beers in the five hours he was present in
  the establishment.Â  Id. at 83, 399 S.E.2d at 14.Â  In addition, the
  accident occurred only fifteen to twenty minutes after the patron left, and the
  establishment was the only one which the patron frequented that evening.Â  Id.Â  In Alaniz, the Texas Court of Appeals found that the temporal proximity
  between the patronâ€™s exit from the establishment, and a convenience store video
  captured after the accident occurred, some fifty to fifty-five minutes after
  the patron left, was too great.Â  Alaniz, 165 S.W.3d at 15. Â The Alaniz court noted that â€œalthough evidence of [patron]â€™s obvious intoxication and the
  requisite proximate causation may be established by circumstantial evidence, the evidence must transcend mere suspicion and conjecture.â€Â  Alaniz,
  165 S.W.3d at 14-15.Â  
In Romano,
  the Court of Appeals in New York also found that circumstantial evidence was
  admissible to prove intoxication; however, it expressly rejected as speculative
  and conclusory, evidence such as the retrograde analysis in the case at hand,
  because the academic conclusion of a personâ€™s level of toxicity, arrived at
  after-the-fact, was not based on any facts or data contemporaneous to the sale
  of the alcohol.Â  Romano, 684 N.E.2d at 22; see also Sorenson
    v. Denny Nash, Inc., 671 N.Y.S.2d 559, 560-61 (N.Y. App. Div. 1998) (applying
  the analysis in Romano).Â  Finally in Ladd, retrograde analysis
  evidence was admitted as evidence of what the personâ€™s intoxication would have
  been when the accident occurred, where the BAC test was not administered until
  later; however, objections to this evidence were not properly preserved, so the Ladd court did not rule on its propriety.Â  Ladd, 675 N.E.2d at 1213.
Section 61-4-580(2)
  clearly states that an actual sale of alcohol to an intoxicated person
  is prohibited.Â  (emphasis added).Â  Even taking the evidence at trial in the
  light most favorable to Hartfield, as we are required to do on review of a
  motion for a directed verdict, the record is simply devoid of any evidence that
  the Pub actually sold Helton alcohol while he was there, or that Helton was drinking
  while present.Â  As a result, we need not decide whether retrograde analysis
  would be admissible in a proper case because, in the absence of evidence of a
  sale, the directed verdict was properly granted.Â  
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, J., and GEATHERS, J., concur.


[1] Retrograde extrapolation begins with the known
  variable of what a personâ€™s BAC is at the time of testing, and then
  extrapolates that figure back, taking certain assumptions and known variables
  into consideration, in order to create a drinking timeline as a rough estimate
  of what the personâ€™s BAC would have been at any point during the day of
  drinking.Â

a.  Custodial
  Interrogation
In the case sub judice, Kirton was not subjected to
  custodial interrogation at his bond hearing, even though he was in custody at
  the time.Â  There is no evidence that he was subjected to questioning by law
  enforcement or any other interrogation such that the requirement to provide Miranda warnings attached.
â€œInterrogation is either express questioning or its functional
  equivalent. It includes words or actions on the part of police (other than
  those normally attendant to arrest and custody) that the police should know are
  reasonably likely to elicit an incriminating response.â€Â  State v. Kennedy,
  325 S.C. 295, 303, 479 S.E.2d 838, 842 (Ct. App. 1996), affâ€™d as modified,
  333 S.C. 426, 510 S.E.2d 714 (1998) (citing Rhode Island v. Innis, 446
  U.S. 291 (1980); State v. Franklin, 299 S.C. 133, 382 S.E.2d 911 (1989)).

	The Miranda decision is meant to preserve the privilege
  against self-incrimination during interrogation of a suspect in a police
  dominated atmosphere. The police dominated atmosphere generates â€œinherently
  compelling pressures which work to undermine the individual's will to resist
  and to compel him to speak where he would not otherwise do so freely.â€

State v. Lynch, 375 S.C. 628, 635, 654 S.E.2d 292, 296
  (Ct. App. 2007) (quoting Illinois v. Perkins, 496 U.S. at 296).
Not all encounters with law enforcement require Miranda warnings to be given.Â  Requiring a suspect to perform field sobriety tests
  during a traffic stop does not constitute detainment sufficient to rise to the
  level of â€œcustodial interrogation.â€Â  State v. Peele, 298 S.C. 63, 66,
  378 S.E.2d 254, 256 (1989).Â  
In discussing the difference between Sixth Amendment right to
  counsel and the Fifth Amendment right as memorialized in Miranda, the
  United States Supreme Court has held a suspectâ€™s Miranda rights are only
  invoked by â€œsome statement that can reasonably be construed to be an expression
  of a desire for the assistance of an attorney in dealing with custodial
  interrogation by the police.Â  Requesting the assistance of an attorney at a
  bail hearing does not bear that construction.â€Â  McNeil v. Wisconsin, 501
  U.S. 171, 179 (1991) (emphasis removed).Â  The Court in McNeil found a
  bail hearing is not a setting in which custodial interrogation takes place
  requiring Miranda warnings.Â  The Illinois Supreme Court recognized:

	It is not surprising that virtually every Supreme Court opinion
  involving Miranda has used the phrase â€œcustodial interrogation.â€Â  It is
  custodial interrogation with which Miranda was concerned.Â  . . .Â  While in
  court on a bond hearing, a defendant is not subject to interrogation, and the
  need for Miranda is not yet present.Â  . . .Â  Absent the interplay of custody
  and interrogation, an individualâ€™s privilege against self-incrimination is not
  threatened.

People v.
  Villalobos, 737 N.E.2d
  639, 645 (Ill. 2000).Â  
The Maryland Court of Appeals dealt with a remarkably similar case
  in Fenner v. State, 846 A.2d 1020 (Md. 2004).Â  At Fennerâ€™s bail hearing,
  he was asked, â€œIs there anything youâ€™d like to tell me about yourself, sir?â€Â  Id. at 1023.Â  During the colloquy that followed, statements were made which the
  State sought to admit at his trial.Â  Fenner sought to suppress the statements
  because he was not given his Miranda warnings.Â  The court held that Miranda warnings were not required because Fenner was not subject to custodial
  interrogation.Â  Specifically, the court reasoned â€œany questions asked of an
  arrestee at a bail hearing should normally be general and unrelated to evidence
  gathering or prosecution.â€Â  Id. at 1028.Â  The court announced:

	We hold that nothing in the setting of petitionerâ€™s January 10,
  2001 bail review hearing can be said to have coerced him into making his
  inculpatory statement.Â  The question posed, â€œIs there anything you'd like to
  tell me about yourself, sir?,â€ was a routine question to ask in a setting such
  as a bail review hearing.Â  Questions posed to an arrestee by a judge regarding
  matters relevant to bail, asked in the setting of a bail review hearing, do not
  normally amount to an â€œinterrogationâ€ requiring that the arrestee be again
  advised of his Miranda rights in order that his responses may be later
  admitted into evidence at his merits trial.

Id. at 1030 (footnote omitted). 
Kirton was not questioned by law enforcement or anyone associated
  with law enforcement.Â  He was asked a single question by a magistrate presiding
  over his bond hearing.Â  The innocuous question related solely to the setting of
  the bond and in no way was intended to elicit an incriminating response.Â  There
  was no requirement that Kirton be advised of his Miranda rights and no
  requirement that a waiver of those rights be obtained.Â  The trial court did not
  err in admitting into evidence Kirtonâ€™s voluntary statement made at his bond
  hearing.
b.  Miranda
  Warnings and Voluntary Waiver
Kirton contends he was not properly advised of his Miranda rights
  and, even if he was advised, the State failed to demonstrate he voluntarily waived
  his rights.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe well-known Miranda rights are that the accused must be
  informed of: the right to remain silent; any statement made may be used as
  evidence against him or her; and the right to the presence of an attorney.â€Â  State
    v. Lynch, 375 S.C. 628, 633 n.5, 654 S.E.2d 292, 295 n.5 (Ct. App. 2007)
  (citing State v. Kennedy, 325 S.C. 295, 303, 479 S.E.2d 838, 842 (Ct.
  App. 1996), affâ€™d as modified, 333 S.C. 426, 510 S.E.2d 714 (1998)).
During the in camera hearing, Judge Dunn testified, â€œWhen
  he came in, I advised him that this was his bond hearing; not his trial.Â  And I
  read him his rights.â€Â  Judge Dunn elaborated about the rights he explained to
  Kirton: â€œadvised him that he has the right to remain silent; and anything that
  he says can be held against him [in] a court of law. . . .Â  And I asked himâ€”I
  said: Do you understand that?â€Â  According to Judge Dunn, Kirton answered that
  he did.Â  The trial court asked Judge Dunn, â€œDo you as a common course . . .
  advise defendants of their right to have an attorney; and that if they cannot
  afford an attorney . . . to contact the Public Defenderâ€™s Office?â€Â  Judge Dunn
  responded, â€œYes sir.â€
The State introduced the Magistrateâ€™s Bond Hearing Checklist,
  which indicated a check mark beside â€œDefendant was advised of his right to
  counselâ€”to an appointed counsel if financial unable.â€Â  It was only after
  advising Kirton of his rights and going through the checklist that Judge Dunn
  asked Kirton if there was anything he wanted to say to the court.Â  At the in
    camera hearing, Kirton testified that Judge Dunn went down the checklist
  and â€œ[h]e read me rights . . . and then set my bond.â€Â  The evidence in the
  record amply supports a finding that Kirton was properly advised of his Miranda rights and given the opportunity to waive them.
There is no indication Kirton was under the influence of drugs or
  alcohol.Â  There is no evidence Kirton was coerced into making a statement, was promised
  anything in exchange for his statement, or made his statement by anything other
  than his own volition.Â  Judge Dunnâ€™s testimony supports the conclusion that
  Kirton voluntarily waived his rights and freely made his statement to the
  magistrate.Â  The trial courtâ€™s admission of Kirtonâ€™s statement did not
  constitute error.
III.  time and place evidence 

Kirton
  avers the trial court erred in allowing testimony by the Stateâ€™s expert
  witness, Dr. Carol Rahter, that went beyond the corroborative testimony allowed
  by Rule 801(d)(1)(D), SCRE.Â  Rule 801(d)(1)(D) states, â€œA statement is not
  hearsay if . . . [t]he declarant testifies at the trial or hearing and is
  subject to cross-examination concerning the statement, and the statement is (D)
  consistent with the declarantâ€™s testimony in a criminal sexual conduct case or
  attempted criminal sexual conduct case where the declarant is the alleged
  victim and the statement is limited to the time and place of the incident.â€
a.  Preservation
The
  issue Kirton raises is not properly preserved for review on appeal.Â  Kirton
  relies on a motion made prior to trial to allege the issues are properly
  preserved for review on appeal.Â  Prior to trial, Kirtonâ€™s counsel stated, â€œI
  have one motion that the Court caution the State that any corroboration of
  [Victimâ€™s] allegation of sexual abuse be strictly limited to time and place, and
  I would impose that on each of the testifying witnesses and also to Dr. Rahter
  as she testified also.â€Â  The court did not consider the motion to be a motion in
    limine, but as a motion â€œto simply be sure that the witnesses do not come
  in and without an understanding.â€Â  The court explained:

	I would
  expect that if questions come up which defense counsel feels are proper
  questions and you feel are improper questions, you will interpose an
  appropriate objection, and likewise, if questions are asked that you feel are
  proper and defense counsel feels are improper, . . . he will impose proper
  objections.

The
  ruling by the court prior to trial was not a final ruling and the court
  expected counsel to offer a contemporaneous objection if allegedly improper
  testimony is offered.Â  Significant testimony occurred between the pre-trial
  motion and Dr. Rahterâ€™s testimony that is challenged.Â  The pre-trial motion,
  therefore, did not act to preserve the issue for review on appeal.Â  See State
    v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 642-43, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001) (finding
  only when no evidence is taken between the trial courtâ€™s in limine ruling and the admission at trial of the evidence is the issue preserved
  without a contemporaneous objection). 
Kirton
  alleges the objections were entered into the record by counsel.Â  Kirton points
  to two instances where Dr. Rahterâ€™s testimony included allegedly improper
  hearsay testimony beyond that which is allowed by Rule 801(d)(1)(D).Â  The first
  instance is when Dr. Rahter was testifying regarding the beginning of the
  sexual abuse Victim suffered.Â  Dr. Rahter stated she was told by Victim that
  the first time the abuse occurred was when Victim was seven and the last time
  was about four weekends before their interview.Â  No contemporaneous objection was
  made when Dr. Rahter testified about the abuse.Â  See State v. Johnson,
  363 S.C. 53, 58-59, 609 S.E.2d 520, 523 (2005) (â€œTo preserve an issue for
  review there must be a contemporaneous objection that is ruled upon by the
  trial court. . . .Â  If a party fails to properly object, the party is
  procedurally barred from raising the issue on appeal.â€).
When
  Dr. Rahter testified regarding whether the medical findingsâ€”that Victimâ€™s hymen
  had been transected by a â€œpenetrating injuryâ€â€”and Victimâ€™s testimony were consistent,
  Kirton failed to object on any grounds.Â  Kirton directs this Court to an
  exchange with the trial court after Dr. Rahterâ€™s testimony and counselâ€™s objection
  after the presentation of Kirtonâ€™s case before he rested.Â  Neither of these
  objections was contemporaneous to Dr. Rahterâ€™s testimony.Â  Kirtonâ€™s counsel
  even admitted to the trial court: â€œI know I did not contemporaneously object
  when she answered that but the Court prior to that made its ruling, and Iâ€™m
  going to see if I can preserve it by putting the sidebar on.â€Â  
b.  Cumulative
Even
  if properly preserved, the allegedly improper testimony is cumulative to other
  un-objected to testimony.Â  Several other witnesses testified regarding Victimâ€™s
  statements about abuse by Kirton.Â  The other witnessesâ€™ testimony identifies
  Kirton as the perpetrator and provides some details of the abuse.Â  See State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) (stating
  that any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to
  evidence is harmless); State v. Johnson, 298 S.C. 496, 499, 381 S.E.2d
  732, 733 (1989) (â€œThe admission of improper evidence is harmless where it is
  merely cumulative to other evidence.â€).
c.  Not Improper Testimony
The
  testimony by Dr. Rahter was not improper hearsay testimony.Â  The first instance
  alleged in Kirtonâ€™s brief included only the date or time frame of the alleged
  abuse.Â  This testimony is properly allowed under Rule 801(d)(1)(D), SCRE.Â  
The
  second instance involved testimony regarding the medical findings by Dr.
  Rahter.Â  This testimony was properly admitted as evidence used by the expert
  witness in forming her opinion that the medical findings were consistent with
  the interview conducted with Victim.Â  Dr. Rahter explained why the statements
  and medical findings were significant.Â  The testimony was admitted as forming
  the base of her opinion and not for the truth of the matter asserted.Â  See,
    e.g., Howle v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 288 S.C. 586, 595-596, 344 S.E.2d
  157, 162 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  
The
  issue raised in Kirtonâ€™s brief is not properly preserved for review on appeal,
  the testimony was cumulative to other unobjected-to testimony, and the
  testimony was not improper hearsay.Â  The trial court did not err in admitting
  the testimony.
CONCLUSION
We
  hold the trial court properly denied Kirtonâ€™s motion to exclude evidence of
  prior bad acts.Â  Notwithstanding that Kirtonâ€™s appearance before a magistrate
  at his bond hearing did not require Miranda warnings, Kirton was given
  the Miranda warnings and voluntarily waived his rights by stating he
  needed â€œmental help.â€Â  The trial courtâ€™s admission of this statement was not in
  error.Â  Despite Kirtonâ€™s failure to preserve any objection to Dr. Rahterâ€™s
  testimony, her testimony was proper and cumulative to other unobjected-to
  evidence.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err in admitting her testimony.
Accordingly,
  Kirtonâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.Â  
HUFF
  and THOMAS, JJ., concur.Â

title: Coker v. Cummings
description: In this boundary dispute case, James Coker appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s grant of summary judgment in Respondentsâ€™ favor finding Coker had acquiesced to the boundary lines.  We affirm.
