THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina, Respondent,
				v.
				Rodney R.
      Parker, Jr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Colleton County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge 
Opinion No. 4475
Heard December 11, 2008 â€“ Filed December
  23, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Robert M. Dudek, Deputy Chief Appellate Defender for Capital
  Appeals, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General
  John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.: Â Rodney R. Parker,
  Jr., (â€œParkerâ€) was convicted of the armed robbery of an Ashepoo grocery store
  and the murder of its employee, English Jack Savage.Â  Parker confessed after
  being apprehended.Â  He appeals his conviction arguing the trial judge erred
  ruling his confession was admissible and by denying his motion for a change of
  venue.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
The events leading
  up to Parkerâ€™s confession occurred primarily on the night of December 26, 2003, and into the morning of December 27, 2003.Â  Parker was wanted by law enforcement in connection to numerous crimes. Â Multiple agencies participated
  in the investigation and manhunt including the highway patrol, the South
  Carolina Law Enforcement Division, the Colleton County Sheriffâ€™s Department,
  and the Department of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.Â  The search utilized
  helicopters and two bloodhound units.Â  Joe Boykin, an ATF agent who testified
  at the Jackson v. Denno hearing, became involved with the pursuit of
  Parker because many of the crimes committed were federal offenses.Â  
Authorities
  were tipped off that Parker and his co-defendant, Jaquan Ferrell, had stolen a Mercedes
  Benz in Columbia and were traveling towards Colleton County.Â  Interstate 95 was
  shut down for an hour causing a significant back-up of holiday traffic.Â  The
  various law enforcement agencies created a command post by taking over a rest
  area.Â  Parker and Ferrell were spotted in the car and crashed following a high
  speed chase.Â  The pair fled into a wooded area and spent the night without shelter
  or warm clothing as the temperature dipped below freezing.Â  
Early
  the next morning, Parker and Ferrell were seen running across a dirt road. Â Boykin,
  Investigator Philip Roberson and Officer Hampton Jenkins, both with the
  Colleton County Sheriffâ€™s Department, responded to the area.Â  They eventually observed
  Parker lying on the ground with his hands under his body.Â  Despite being
  commanded to â€œshow us your hands,â€ Boykin testified Parker refused to obey.Â  After
  Roberson discharged a warning shot, Parker jumped up and ran away.Â  Roberson
  and Jenkins both fired as he fled. Â Boykin opined Roberson was shooting to
  kill.Â  Soon after, bloodhounds tracked Parker and he was tackled during a foot
  chase.Â  
When
  Parker was apprehended, Boykin estimated there were approximately thirty agents
  and officers on the scene.Â  Â Boykin asked Parker if he was okay and whether he
  needed a doctor.Â  Parker only complained of being cold and was placed in the
  back of a heated police car.Â  Boykin noted that Parker was angry with Roberson for
  having tried to shoot him.Â  He inquired whether Parker would be willing to
  speak with him and if he wanted his father present.Â  Parker responded
  affirmatively to both questions.Â  After being examined and treated at the
  hospital, Parker confessed at the sheriffâ€™s department.Â  The majority of his
  oral confession was videotaped. Â A jury found him guilty, and he was sentenced
  to life imprisonment for murder and thirty years imprisonment for armed
  robbery.
ISSUES

	(1)  Did the trial court err in determining Parkerâ€™s statement
  was admissible?
	(2)  Did the trial court err in denying Parkerâ€™s motion to
  change venue due to pretrial publicity?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State
    v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006); State v. Wilson,
  345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608
  S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  This court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual
  findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338
  S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000); State v. Amerson, 311 S.C. 316, 428
  S.E.2d 871 (1993); State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct.
  App. 2004).Â  
The
  trial judge determines the admissibility of a statement upon proof of its
  voluntariness by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  State v. Miller, 375
  S.C. 370, 378, 652 S.E.2d 444, 448 (Ct. App. 2007) (citing State v.
    Washington, 296 S.C. 54, 55, 370 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1998); State v. Smith,
  268 S.C. 349, 354, 234 S.E.2d 19, 21 (1977)); State v. Arrowood, 375
  S.C. 359, 365, 652 S.E.2d 438, 441 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  If admitted, the jury must
  then determine whether the statement was given freely and voluntarily beyond a
  reasonable doubt.Â  Washington, 296 S.C. at 55-56, 370 S.E.2d at 612.
â€œFactual
  conclusions as to the voluntariness of a statement will not be disturbed on
  appeal unless so manifestly erroneous as to show an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Arrowood,
  375 S.C. at 365, 652 S.E.2d at 441; Baccus, 367 S.C. at 48, 625 S.E.2d
  at 220; State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 551 S.E.2d 240 (2001); State v.
    Kennedy, 333 S.C. 426, 429, 510 S.E.2d 714, 715 (1998); State v. Von
      Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 242, 471 S.E.2d 689, 695 (1996).Â Â  â€œIn criminal
  cases, appellate courts are bound by fact finding in response to preliminary
  motions where there has been conflicting testimony or where the findings are
  supported by the evidence and not clearly wrong or controlled by an error of
  law.â€Â  State v. Asbury, 328 S.C. 187, 193, 493 S.E.2d 349, 352 (1997)
  (citing State v. Amerson, 311 S.C. at 320, 428 S.E.2d at 873); State
    v. Franklin, 299 S.C. 133, 138, 382 S.E.2d 911, 914 (1989). Â â€œWhen
  reviewing a trial courtâ€™s ruling concerning voluntariness, this Court does not
  reevaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence, but simply determines whether the trial courtâ€™s ruling is supported
  by any evidence.â€Â  Saltz, 346 S.C at 136, 551 S.E.2d at 252; State v.
    Breeze, 379 S.C. 538, 543, 665 S.E.2d 247, 250 (Ct. App. 2008); Miller,
  375 S.C. at 378-79, 652 S.E.2d at 448.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  In camera Hearing and Ruling on Oral
  and Transcribed Statements.
Parker argues the trial court erred in ruling his statement was
  admissible because he: (1) was a minor, (2) was examined at a hospital after
  being apprehended, (3) spent the night outdoors in the cold, (4) was shot at by
  police, (5) spent three and a half hours being interviewed, (6) confessed to an
  agent who admittedly sought to manipulate him, and (7) because his father
  â€œaided the police.â€Â  After examining the record, we disagree. 
â€œA
  criminal defendant is deprived of due process if his conviction is founded, in
  whole or in part, upon an involuntary confession.â€Â  State v. Pittman,
  373 S.C. 527, 565, 647 S.E.2d 144, 164 (2007) (citing Jackson v Denno,
  378 U.S. 368, 377 (1964)), cert. denied, __ U.S. __, 128 S. Ct. 1872, 170 L. Ed. 2d 751 (2008).Â  In State v. Miller, this court instructed:

	The
  process for determining whether a statement is voluntary, and thus admissible,
  is bifurcated; it involves determinations by both the judge and the jury.Â  First,
  the trial judge must conduct an evidentiary hearing, outside the presence of
  the jury, where the State must show the statement was voluntarily made by a
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368, 376, 84 S. Ct. 1774, 12 L.Ed. 2d 908 (1964).Â  If the statement is found to have been given
  voluntarily, it is then submitted to the jury, where its voluntariness must be
  established beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v. Washington, 296 S.C.
  54, 56, 370 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1988).

Miller, 375 S.C. at 380, 652 S.E.2d at 448; Arrowood,
  375 S.C. at 366, 652 S.E.2d at 442.Â  See also Lego v. Twomey, 404
  U.S. 477, 489 (â€œ[T]he prosecution must prove . . . by a preponderance of the
  evidence that the confession was voluntary.â€); State v. Smith, 268 S.C. 349,
  354, 234 S.E.2d 19, 21 (1977) (â€œIt has been uniformly held, a confession may be
  introduced upon proof of its voluntariness by a preponderance of the
  evidence.â€); State v. Neely, 271 S.C. 33, 40, 244 S.E.2d 522, 526 (1978)
  (â€œ[T]he burden is on the State to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that
  [these] rights were voluntarily waived.â€).
Upon motion of the defense counsel, the trial judge held a
  pretrial Jackson v. Denno hearing to determine the admissibility of
  Parkerâ€™s oral and written statements.Â  The State presented ATF Agent Joe Boykin
  and three members of the Colleton County Sheriffâ€™s Department:Â  Investigator
  Philip Roberson, former investigator Leslie Jamison, and Investigator Angela
  McAllister Stallings.Â  The judge viewed the videotaped portion of the oral
  confession.
Boykin told the trial judge details concerning how he, as a
  federal agent, came to be involved in the investigation and manhunt.Â  He
  explained he, Roberson and Jenkins spotted Parker in the woods, ordered him to
  show his hands, and that shots were fired as he ran.Â  Parker was eventually
  tackled, handcuffed and placed in a heated police car.Â  In Robersonâ€™s presence,
  Boykin read Parker his Miranda warnings.Â  At the time, Parkerâ€™s main
  complaint was that he was cold. Â Boykin estimated the arrest occurred at seven
  or eight oâ€™clock in the morning. 
Parkerâ€™s Miranda warnings were given by Boykin a second
  time at the sheriffâ€™s department prior to the questioning, but Boykin had no
  knowledge that a written waiver form was provided.Â  The videotaping was not
  initiated until fifteen to twenty minutes after Parker had been placed in the
  interview room because the equipment was locked in an adjoining office.Â  Boykin
  discussed only â€œgeneralitiesâ€ as they waited for Parkerâ€™s father to arrive.Â  When
  asked to describe Parkerâ€™s physical appearance at the sheriffâ€™s office, Boykin
  explained:

	Tired.Â  He had been in the woods all night long.Â  It was cold that
  night.Â  But he was certainly more comfortable at that point and time than he
  had been, because it was a cold night.Â  And also he had been scared.Â  He had
  been, you know, hiding from police all night long.Â  But he seemed to be calm.Â 
  Or calm, much more calm than having been in the woods all night and with his
  apprehension that occurred previously.Â  And I mean, we spoke easily to each
  other.Â  He didnâ€™t seem apprehensive to talk to me.Â  I was very kind to him.Â 
  And spoke respectfully to him.
	. . . 
	And I inquired as to his condition.Â  If he was okay.Â  He said he
  was.Â  He was just tired.Â  He had some cuts and some dings from, you know,
  running through the woods the night before.Â  And I had inquired earlier if he
  would like to see his father.Â  And have his father there.Â  And he said yes.Â  So
  I made arrangements to get Mr. Parker, Sr. to come to the sheriffâ€™s
  department.Â  

Boykin knew Parker had spent time with the Department of Juvenile
  Justice, but was unaware of his intellectual capacity or level of education.Â Â 
  He said Parker spoke coherently and did not appear to be under the influence of
  alcohol or intoxicants. Â When Boykin asked if he wanted an attorney, â€œ[Parker]
  said no.Â  He said he was fine.Â  He responded that he would agree to be
  interviewed.Â  And I asked him did he want his father there and he said, yes.â€Â 
  Boykin denied being coercive or threatening.Â  He did not make any
  representations that Parker would be tried as a juvenile or an adult or receive
  a life sentence unless he spoke.Â  Although Boykin admitted he did not serve the
  Stateâ€™s arrest warrants for murder or armed robbery, he remembered telling Parker
  he was arrested under state charges, not federal, and was being charged with the
  grocery store robbery.Â  Because the taped confession lasted at least an hour
  and a half, adding on the fifteen to twenty minutes missed before the video equipment
  was activated, Boykin estimated his interview lasted nearly two hours.Â  
At the Denno hearing, Boykin was cross-examined concerning
  his interrogation techniques:

	
		
			Q:   
			Isnâ€™t it true that the particular technique that 
			you use is called the [Reid] technique?
 
		
		
			A:  
			I have heard of the [Reid] technique.  Iâ€™ve 
			never been specifically instructed in the [Reid] technique.  I 
			think thatâ€™s a school, itâ€™s an advanced school.  Iâ€™ve never 
			gone to it.  But I am familiar with it.  I mean, Iâ€™ve 
			familiar with some of the, you know, fundamentals I guess.  My 
			â€“ I mean, my way of interviewing is I always try to be nice to 
			folks, you know, and treat them with respect.  And I find for 
			me that gets me a lot further in talking to folks than being 
			belligerent or condescending.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Isnâ€™t it true, Agent Boykin, that the [Reid] 
			technique involves breaking the defendant down first of all?  
			And then after breaking him down, then you give him some moral 
			justification or rationalization?  You kind of back him into a 
			corner and break him down.  And then you back him into a corner 
			with the, you know, showing him the pictures and the evidence like 
			you did between the two.
 
		
		
			A:  
			I am not sure if thatâ€™s all part of the [Reid] 
			technique per se.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			And then you give him a morally justified reason 
			for what youâ€™re accusing him of doing.
 
		
		
			A: 
			I use that as a technique personally.  I use 
			the expression of giving somebody an out.  I mean thatâ€™s what 
			youâ€™re saying basically.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Thatâ€™s part ofâ€”
 
		
		
			A:  
			Itâ€™s hard for somebody to admit when theyâ€™ve done 
			something wrong without any justification.  And so a lot of 
			times when I interview folks, I try to craft my questioning in such 
			a way that, you know, if they want to admit theyâ€™ve done something 
			wrong, to help them make that admission.  
 
		
		
			Q:   
			Isnâ€™t it true, Agent Boykin, and when you said, 
			â€œRodney [] I know you didnâ€™t mean toâ€”
 
		
		
			A:
			Right, I did say that.
 
		
		
			Q:
			--to shoot Mr. Savage.  I know you didnâ€™t mean 
			to kill him.â€
 
		
		
			A:
			Right.  
 
		
		
			Q: 
			 â€œI know you must have been nervous.  I 
			know you must have been scared you were going to get shot by all 
			that.â€
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes, sir.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			That was a deceptive [Reid] technique that is used 
			to try to involuntarily gain a confession, isnâ€™t that right?
 
		
		
			A:
			I donâ€™t know about the [Reid] technique per se.  
			But, I mean, I did say that.  And I did say it with the hopes 
			that I could give Mr. Parker a platform if you will, to admit that 
			he shot Mr. Savage.  And I thought it would be easier for him 
			to come out with the admission if he thought that I thought there 
			was some justification for it.  And that he was not the bad guy 
			that he had been portrayed or perceived to be; that maybe there was 
			a reason that he shot him.  Maybe, you know, maybe he was 
			scared.  Maybe he was upset.  Maybe Mr. Savage did 
			something that frightened him or upset him and made him shoot.  
			But when I do interviews, you know, I try to create an environment 
			for someone to be comfortable with me, to want to talk to me.  
			And in effect, get if off their chest and have an opportunity to 
			unload.  
 
		
		
			 
			And thatâ€™s what I was trying to do with Mr. Parker when I
  interviewed him, is try to put him at ease, and try to give him an out, if you
  will, to make that admission.Â  And thatâ€™s certainly accurate.Â  
		
	

Investigator
  Roberson was with Boykin on December 27, 2003, when Parker was given his Miranda warnings in the back of the police car.Â  He first became involved with the
  investigation after being called to the grocery store the night of the robbery
  and shooting.Â  He worked extensively on the case until Parker was arrested.Â 
  Roberson participated in the car chase but his vehicle was unable to keep up.Â 
  He told the trial judge another officer, Captain Buddy Hill, shot out the
  Mercedesâ€™ windows and tires prior to the wreck.Â  
Robersonâ€™s
  testimony about the efforts made to find Parker in the woods and the subsequent
  arrest corroborated that of Boykin.Â  After spotting Parker, Roberson said he
  refused to show his hands leading him to believe he had a gun.Â  He admitted
  firing twenty-eight rounds as Parker ran away.Â  Roberson never interviewed
  Parker, but, immediately after his arrest, â€œtalked to him to see howâ€”what kind
  of mind set he was in so I would know what we were dealing with when we were
  transporting him.â€Â  He denied telling Parker that he would go to jail for the
  rest of his life.Â  
Leslie
  Jamison, an investigator with the Colleton County Sheriffâ€™s Department at the
  time of Parkerâ€™s arrest, was the case officer in the murder and armed robbery
  investigation.Â  She was with Boykin at the department when he advised Parker of
  his Miranda rights and conducted the interview.Â  Jamison agreed no
  written waiver of Parkerâ€™s Miranda rights was prepared. Â She stated: (1)
  neither she nor Boykin used threats, coercion, or promises, (2) Parker appeared
  to understand the questions asked during the interview, (3) he did not appear
  to be under the influence of intoxicants or alcohol, and (4) he did not appear
  injured.Â  To the best of her knowledge, Parkerâ€™s statement was given freely and
  voluntarily.Â  
Jamison
  explained the arrest warrants were not served until January 9, 2004, because
  Parker was a minor and her supervisor told her to wait.Â  She confirmed Boykin
  talked to Parker subsequent to the hospital visit and asked if he wanted his
  father present.Â  She denied speaking with Parker about his father.Â  Jamison disagreed
  that Parker was interviewed the afternoon following his arrest because he was
  at a vulnerable point.Â  Taking into consideration that Parker had experienced a
  car crash, been shot at, and spent a night in the cold, Jamison opined Parker
  had spent other nights in the woods and been pursued by law enforcement on
  previous occasions.Â  Â Â She did not tell Parker exactly what he was charged with
  or the penalties involved.Â  Although she was aware there would be an attempt to
  try Parker as an adult, she did not communicate this information to him.Â  She
  knew of Parkerâ€™s education level but not that of his father.
Colleton County Sheriffâ€™s Department Investigator Angela
  McAllister Stallings took Parkerâ€™s written statement following his interview
  with Boykin.Â  She testified she transcribed the statement as Parker spoke and,
  if he spoke too fast, she would ask him to â€œhold on.â€Â  Although unable to remember
  why she wrote the statement rather than Parker, she asserted the practice was not
  unusual.Â  She confirmed Parker and Ferrell were taken to the hospital to be
  checked for hypothermia after their arrest and prior to their arrival at the
  sheriffâ€™s department.Â  One of them had a foot checked for frostbite.
Stallings averred Jamison and Boykin gave Parker his Miranda warnings, but admitted she was not present either time.Â  With custodial
  interviews Stallings initiates, she usually has a written waiver form but conceded
  none was provided to Parker.Â  The written statement began at 3:40 p.m. and concluded at 5:40 p.m.Â  She did not recall Parker crying or hanging his head.Â 
  The written statement, which Stallings read at the Denno hearing,
  declared:

	[Ferrell] picked me up in a gray ford taurus.Â  It had Orangeburg
  paper tags on it.Â  I thought it was a rental car.Â  We came back to Colleton County.Â  We went to Greed Pond and parked at Woodâ€™s store.Â  We were in the ford taurus.Â 
  We walked from Woodâ€™s store to Ashepoo Grocery.Â  We walked behind the store.Â 
  We came up on the south side of the building and stood there for awhile to wait
  for the least amount of cars in the parking lot.Â  We went inside.Â  I went
  behind the cash register and pointed the gun at Jack and [Ferrell] pointed his
  gun at a customer.Â  I told Jack to open up the cash register and he started
  yelling the name Lucious.Â  I got scared when he started yelling for him.Â 
  Before we went in, [Ferrell] said if he called Lucious, he would come out and
  shoot us.Â  He walked towards me and I backed up and the gun went off.Â  He
  started backing up.Â  I grabbed the register and ran.Â  As [Ferrell] was watching
  the customer, his gun fell apart.Â  After I took the register, we ran out and
  went left, ran behind the store and ran back through the field to the car and
  pulled out on the highway and went right.
	Yesterday we came to Walterboro in the white Benz.Â  A black jeep
  was following us so I pulled off the road.Â  We got to the interstate and got on
  and saw all the black and golds. I pulled over and the black and gold pulled in
  behind me and turned the blue lights on.Â  [Ferrell] said go-go and I took off.Â
